revision.text:
The '''London Conference of 1832''' was an international conference convened to establish a stable government in [[First Hellenic Republic|Greece]]. Negotiations between the three Great Powers ([[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Britain]], [[July Monarchy|France]] and [[Russian Empire|Russia]]) resulted in the establishment of the [[Kingdom of Greece]] under a [[Otto of Greece|Bavarian Prince]]. The decisions were ratified in the [[Treaty of Constantinople (1832)|Treaty of Constantinople]] later that year. The treaty followed the [[Akkerman Convention]] which had previously recognized another territorial change in the [[Balkans]], the [[suzerainty]] of [[Principality of Serbia]].<ref> {{Citation | last = Vitev | first = Plamen | author-link = Plamen Vitev | last2 = Parvev | first2 = Ivan | author2-link = Ivan Parvev | last3 = Baramova | first3 = Maria | author3-link = Maria Baramova | last4 = Racheva | first4 = Vania | author4-link = Vania Racheva | title = Empires and Peninsulas: Southeastern Europe between Karlowitz and the Peace of Adrianople, 1699–1829 | place = | publisher = | origyear = |date=June 2010 | volume = | edition = | chapter = | chapterurl = | page = | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Cz7pbGvCqhwC&lpg=PA147&ots=rjQDIK_NJD&dq=akkerman%20convention%20serbia&pg=PP1#v=onepage&q=akkerman%20convention%20serbia&f=false | archiveurl = | archivedate = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-3-643-10611-7}}</ref>
==Background==
[[Greece]] had won its independence from the [[Ottoman Empire]] in the [[Greek War of Independence]] (1821–1829) with the help of Britain, France and Russia. In the London Protocol of 3 February 1830, the three powers had assigned the borders of the new state. However, when the governor of Greece, [[John Capodistria]] (Ioannis Kapodistrias) (Καποδíστριας) was assassinated in 1831 in [[Nafplion]], the Greek peninsula plunged into confusion. The Great Powers sought a formal end of the war and a recognized government in Greece.
[[Image:Palmerston.jpg|frame|thumbnail|right|15px|As Foreign Secretary, Viscount Palmerston was deeply interested in Greece]]
==Conference of London== In May 1832, British [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston|Palmerston]] convened with French and Russian diplomats, and, without consultation of the Greeks, decided that Greece should be a monarchy. The convention offered the throne to the [[Kingdom of Bavaria|Bavaria]]n Prince, [[Otto of Greece|Otto]]. They also established the line of succession which would pass the crown to Otto's descendants, or his younger brothers should he have no issue. It was also decided that in no case would the crowns of Greece and Bavaria be joined. As co-guarantors of the monarchy, the Great Powers also empowered their ambassadors in [[Constantinople]], the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] capital, to secure the end of the [[Greek War of Independence]].
On 21 July 1832 British ambassador Sir [[Stratford Canning, 1st Viscount Stratford de Redcliffe|Stratford Canning]] and the other representatives concluded the [[Treaty of Constantinople (1832)|Treaty of Constantinople]], which set the boundaries of the new [[Kingdom of Greece]] at a line running from [[Arta, Greece|Arta]] (Αρτα) to [[Volos]] (Βολος).
==References== {{reflist}} * [http://www.heraldica.org/topics/royalty/greece.htm#Convention-1832 Protocol of London, 1832]
{{Greek War of Independence|state=collapsed}}
[[Category:1832 in London]] [[Category:History of modern Greece]] [[Category:Diplomatic conferences in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:19th-century diplomatic conferences]] [[Category:1832 in international relations]] [[Category:Greece–United Kingdom relations]] [[Category:Conferences in London]] [[Category:1832 conferences]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Observances set by the Ethiopian calendar]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
[[File:FDC-MeskelFestivities.jpg|thumb|[[Postmark]]s commemorating Ethiopian First Day Cover, Meskel festivities, December 17, 1974]] '''Meskel''' ({{lang-gez|መስቀል}}, ''mäsqäl'') is an annual [[religious holiday]] in the [[Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church|Ethiopian Orthodox]] and [[Eritrean Orthodox Tewahdo Church|Eritrean Orthodox]] churches, which commemorates the discovery of the [[True Cross]] by the [[Roman Empire|Roman]] Empress Helena ([[Helena of Constantinople|Saint Helena]]) in the fourth century. Meskel occurs on the 17 Meskerem in the [[Ethiopian calendar]] (September 27, [[Gregorian calendar]], or on 28 September in [[leap year]]s).<ref name="rough">{{cite book|last=Rough Guides|first=|authorlink=Rough Guides|title=The Rough Guide to Ethiopia|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-XqKBgAAQBAJ|series=Rough Guide to...|year=2015|isbn=9780241181850|chapter=Festivals}}</ref> "Meskel" (or "Meskal" or "Mesqel", there are various ways to [[Transliteration|transliterate]] from Ge'ez to Latin script) is [[Ge'ez language|Ge'ez]] for "cross".
The festival is known as [[Feast of the Cross|Feast of the Exaltation of the Holy Cross]] in other Orthodox, [[Catholic]] or [[Protestant]] churches. The churches that follow the Gregorian calendar celebrate the feast yearly on September 14.
The feast is held in Meskel Square, named after the festival, in the capital city of Addis Ababa. Religious and civil leaders preside over the celebration,and public figures give speeches and reference biblical themes and stories. Many Ethiopians who live in cities return to their villages to celebrate the national event. When it gets darker, the Demera is burned.<ref>Thomas M Landy, [https://www.catholicsandcultures.org/ethiopia/meskel "Meskel"], ''Catholics & Cultures'' updated June 19, 2015</ref> ==Overview== [[File:Meskel Celebration.jpg|thumb|Meskel celebration at [[Meskel Square]], [[Addis Ababa]] (2016)]] The Meskel celebration includes the burning of a large bonfire, or ''Demera'', based on the belief that Queen Eleni, as she is known, had a revelation in a dream. She was told that she should make a bonfire and that the smoke would show her where the true cross was buried. So she ordered the people of Jerusalem to bring wood and make a huge pile. After adding frankincense to it the bonfire was lit and the smoke rose high up to the sky and returned to the ground, exactly to the spot where the Cross had been buried.<ref>{{cite web | title=Walta Information Center | work=Meskel Being Celebrated Across The Nation | url=http://www.telecom.net.et/~walta/ennews/html/sep/ed270900/html/newsitem_2.html | accessdate=September 14, 2005 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060319160802/http://www.telecom.net.et/~walta/ennews/html/sep/ed270900/html/newsitem_2.html | archivedate=March 19, 2006 | df= }}</ref>
According to local traditions, this ''Demera''-procession takes place in the early evening the day before Meskel or on the day itself. The firewood is decorated with [[Asteraceae|daisies]] prior to the celebration. Charcoal from the remains of the fire is afterwards collected and used by the faithful to mark their foreheads with the shape of a cross (compare [[Ash Wednesday]]). [[Edward Ullendorff]] records a number of beliefs of the meaning of ''Demera'', with some believing that it "marks the ultimate act in the cancellation of sins, while others hold that the direction of the smoke and the final collapse of the heap indicate the course of future events – just as the cloud of smoke the Lord raised over the [[Tabernacle]] offered guidance to the children of Israel (''[[Book of Exodus|Exod.]]'' 40:34–38)."<ref name="ullen-114">Ullendorff, p. 114</ref> [[File:Demera engulfed in flame Meskel 2013.JPG|thumb|''Demera'' engulfed in flames, 2013.]] One explanation for the high rank this festival has in the church calendar is that it is believed that a part of the true Cross has been brought to Ethiopia from Egypt. It is said to be kept at [[Amba Geshen]], which itself has a cross-shaped plan.
According to the Ethiopian Orthodox Church, the discovery of the True Cross is traditionally believed to have been in March, but Meskel was moved to September to avoid holding a festival during [[Lent]], and because the church commemorating the True Cross in [[Jerusalem]] was dedicated during September.<ref>{{cite web | author=Amanuel Sahle | title=The Byzantine Origin of Meskel | work=Shaebia.org | url=http://www.shaebia.org/cgi-bin/artman/exec/view.cgi?archive=3&num=167 | accessdate=September 14, 2005 }}</ref> Ullendorff speculates that Meskel replaced an older festival, with pagan and Hebraic associations, which he believes received its Christian sanction around the reign of Emperor [[Amda Seyon I of Ethiopia|Amda Seyon]] in the fourteenth century. "The most ancient meaning of these feasts – as was also the case in Israel – was no doubt seasonal: the month of Maskaram marked the end of the rains, the resumption of work, and the reopening of communications."<ref name="ullen-114"/>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * Ullendorff, Edward (1968) ''Ethiopia and the Bible'', [[Schweich lectures]] series, Oxford University Press for the British Academy, {{ISBN|0-19-726076-4}}
==External links== {{Commonscat|Meskel}} *[http://www.ethioembassy.org.uk/about_us/festivals_and_Holidays.htm Festival and Holidays] on the website of the Embassy of the Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia in the United Kingdom, with a section on "Meskel - The Finding of the True Cross"
[[Category:Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church]] [[Category:Eritrean Orthodox Tewahedo Church]] [[Category:Christian festivals and holy days]] [[Category:Christian festivals]] [[Category:Non-Gregorian September observances]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox building | name = Millennium Tower | image = Millennium Tower 08-13-13.png | image_caption = Millennium Tower in San Francisco, CA. | location = [[Mission Street|301 Mission Street]]
[[San Francisco]], [[California]] | coordinates = {{coord|37.7904|-122.3961|region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = United States San Francisco Central#California#USA | start_date = 2005 | completion_date = 2009 | opening = April 23, 2009 | building_type = Residential condominiums | antenna_spire = {{convert|645|ft|abbr=on}} | roof = {{convert|605|ft|abbr=on}} | top_floor = {{convert|592|ft|abbr=on}} | unit_count = 419 | floor_count = 58 | elevator_count = 12 | cost = {{US$|350 million}} | floor_area = {{convert|1,151,017|sqft|abbr=on}} | architect = Handel Architects | structural_engineer= DeSimone Consulting Engineers | main_contractor = [[Webcor Builders]] | developer = Millennium Partners | owner = {{nowrap|Mission Street Development, LLC}} | management = | references = {{ctbuh|1801}}{{emporis|149912}}{{SkyscraperPage|6729}} }} '''301 Mission Street''' is a development in the [[South of Market, San Francisco|South of Market]] district of [[downtown San Francisco]]. A mixed-use, primarily residential development, it is the tallest residential building in San Francisco. The blue-gray glass, [[Modern architecture|late-modernist]] buildings are bounded by [[Mission Street|Mission]], Fremont, and Beale Streets, and the north end of the [[San Francisco Transbay development#Transbay Transit Center|Transbay Transit Center]] site. Opened to residents on April 23, 2009, 301 Mission includes two buildings: a 12-story tower located on the northeast of the property, and '''Millennium Tower''', a 58-story, {{convert|645|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} [[condominium]] [[skyscraper]]. In total, the project has 419 residential units, with 53 of those units in the smaller tower. The tower's highest level, 58 floors above the ground,{{cite conference |title = Design of the Tallest Reinforced Concrete Structure in California: A 58-Story Residential Tower in San Francisco |first1 = Derrick D. |last1 = Roorda |first2 = Nicolas J. |last2 = Rodrigues |conference = Structures Congress 2008: Crossing Borders |pages = 1–9 |publisher = American Society of Civil Engineers |doi = 10.1061/41016(314)85 }}{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=A96JR7qkWGgC&pg=PA768 |page = 768 |last = Taranath |first = Bungale S. |title = Reinforced concrete design of tall buildings |publisher = CRC Press |year = 2009 |isbn = 1-4398-0480-X }} is listed as the 60th, because floors [[Thirteenth floor|13]] and 44 are [[Thirteenth floor|missing for superstitious reasons]].{{cite news |last = Dineen |first = J. K. |title = Millennium Tower soars to new heights |url = http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2010/03/29/focus3.html |access-date = March 29, 2011 |newspaper = San Francisco Business Times |date = March 28, 2010 |registration = yes }} The [[French restaurant]] and [[wine bar]] ''International Smoke'' is housed on the ground floor of the skyscraper. Resident services include a private [[concierge]] and access to the {{convert|20,000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} Owner's Club Level, which features amenities such as a private lounge, wine cellar, and fitness center. The development's "lifestyle" program organizes cultural events. In May 2016, residents were informed the main tower was both sinking and tilting,{{cite web |last1 = McPhate |first1 = Mike |title = California Today: A Leaning Tower in San Francisco |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/14/us/california-today-sinking-millennium-tower.html |newspaper = The New York Times |access-date = November 3, 2016 }} resulting in several lawsuits concerning repair costs and whether the tilt had been withheld from buyers. ==Description== Developed by Mission Street Development LLC, an affiliate of Millennium Partners, the {{US$|350 million}} project was designed by [[Handel Architects]], engineered by [[DeSimone Consulting Engineers]] and constructed by [[Webcor Builders]]. At {{convert|645|ft|m}}, it is the tallest concrete structure in San Francisco, the fourth tallest building in San Francisco overall, and the tallest since [[345 California Street]] in 1986.{{cite news |first = J. K. |last = Dineen |title = Millennium Pours on Condos |url = http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2007/06/18/story1.html?page=1 |work = San Francisco Business Times |date = June 15, 2007 |access-date = January 21, 2010 |registration = yes }}{{cite news |first = Patrick |last = Hoge |title = Planners approve 58-story Tower; 301 Mission St. would be S.F.'s 4th-Tallest |url = http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Planners-approve-58-story-tower-301-Mission-St-2563068.php |date = August 1, 2003 |work = San Francisco Chronicle |access-date = September 29, 2007 }}{{cite web |title = 345 California Center |url = https://www.emporis.com/buildings/118794/345-california-center-san-francisco-ca-usa |publisher = Emporis |access-date = August 14, 2007 }} It was also the tallest residential building west of the Mississippi River when finished (later surpassed by [[The Austonian]] in Texas).{{cite web |title = Millennium Tower (San Francisco) |url = http://www.enclos.com/project/millennium_tower/ |publisher = Enclos Corp |access-date = March 11, 2011 |dead-url = yes |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130516012058/http://www.enclos.com/project/millennium_tower/ |archive-date = May 16, 2013 |df = mdy }} The tower is slender, with each floor containing {{convert|14000|sqft|m2}} of floor space. In addition to the 58-story tower, there is a {{convert|125|ft|m|adj=on}}, 11-story tower on the northeast end of the complex. Between the two towers is a {{convert|43|ft|m|adj=on}}, two-story glass [[Atrium (architecture)|atrium]]. In total, the project has 419 units. The residences are pricey; a penthouse unit sold for US$13 million in December 2016.{{cite news |first = M. |last = Robinson |title = A tech exec just bought the penthouse in San Francisco's sinking skyscraper for $13 million |url = http://www.businessinsider.com/millennium-tower-penthouse-sold-2016-12 |work = Business Insider |date = December 16, 2016 |access-date = January 2, 2017 }}{{cite news |title = High-end home sales soar in Bay Area |url = http://www.sfgate.com/business/article/High-end-home-sales-soar-in-Bay-Area-3227923.php |work = San Francisco Chronicle |date = February 16, 2008 |access-date = February 17, 2008 |first = James |last = Temple }} The bottom 25 floors of the main tower are called Residences while the floors from 26 to the top have the name Grand Residences. (As is common in many high-rises, there is no thirteenth floor because of superstitions about [[triskaidekaphobia]]. Neither is there a forty-fourth floor, because the number four is considered unlucky by many Asians.Claus, Kyle Scott. "[https://www.bostonmagazine.com/news/2016/02/08/millennium-tower-boston-44-floor/ The Millennium Tower Has No 44th Floor Because of an Asian Superstition]." ''Boston'' magazine, 8 Feb. 2016. Retrieved 6 Aug. 2018.) The 53 units in the separate 12-story tower are called the City Residences. Below street level, there are 434 parking spaces in a five-level subterranean garage located under the 11-story tower. The building is located next to the site of the [[San Francisco Transbay development#Transbay Transit Center|Transbay Transit Center]]. Overall, the tower's design is intended to resemble a translucent crystal, and is a landmark for the [[San Francisco Transbay development|Transbay Redevelopment]] and the southern skyline of San Francisco.{{cite news |title = A chance to reach new heights / Towers could energize S.F. skyline |url = http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/place/article/A-chance-to-reach-new-heights-Towers-could-2545550.php |work = San Francisco Chronicle |first = John |last = King |date = December 21, 2003 |access-date = September 29, 2007 }} The development is also home to International Smoke, a restaurant and bar under the direction of [[Ayesha Curry]] and Chef [[Michael Mina]], located on the ground floor of the skyscraper.{{cite news |first = Damion |last = Matthews |title = RN74 at the Millennium Tower |url = http://sfluxe.com/2009/05/25/rn74-at-the-millennium-tower/ |publisher = SFLUXE |date = May 25, 2009 |access-date = March 11, 2011 }}[http://blog.sfgate.com/ontheblock/2015/09/24/rare-peek-into-ultra-luxe-millennium-tower-corner-unit/ "Rare peek into S.F.’s ultra-luxe Millennium Tower corner unit"], Anna Marie Erwert, [[SFGate]], September 24, 2015 ==History== [[File:Millennium Tower, San Francisco, in August 2016.jpg|thumb|The Millennium Tower in August 2016]] Millennium Partners first proposed the development in 2002 with 163 condominiums, 108 rentals and a 136-unit "extended stay" hotel rooms.{{cite news |url = http://www.sfgate.com/default/article/58-story-skyscraper-seeking-S-F-approval-2834584.php |title = 58-story skyscraper seeking S.F. approval / Proposal for city's fourth-highest tower |first = Gerald D. |last = Adams |date = May 18, 2002 |access-date = December 28, 2013 |newspaper = San Francisco Chronicle }} The project was approved in 2003 by the S.F. Planning Commission 4–1 and construction began in 2005. The only against vote came from Planning Commissioner Sue Lee. The development was the first high rise built downtown in 20 years. According to ''Modern Luxury'', a proposed 52-story skyscraper at nearby 80 Natoma by developer Jack Myers which would also have a similar poured concrete construction, was rejected by the city's Department of Building Inspections (DBI) after an outside peer review. The Millennium Tower received no such scrutiny, since Millennium Partners would not submit to a peer review, as that study would have potentially delayed construction by years.{{cite web |url = https://modernluxury.com/san-francisco/story/the-big-sink |title = The Big Sink |work = Modern Luxury |access-date = November 5, 2017 }} Treadwell & Rollo, the geotechnical engineer for Millennium Tower, were also the geotechnical engineer for the scrapped project at 80 Natoma.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nbcbayarea.com/news/local/Troubles-Plaguing-Leaning-Sinking-Millennium-Tower-Could-Have-Been-Avoided-New-Documents-Show-391468911.html|title=Millennium Tower's Sinking Foretold by Earlier Project|work=NBC Bay Area|access-date=2018-10-13|language=en}} On September 6, 2010, [[Dan Goodwin]], also known as ''SpiderDan'' and ''Skyscraperman'', scaled the outside of the tower using suction cups. Following the climb, Goodwin was arrested by the San Francisco police, who charged him with trespassing and creating a public nuisance.{{cite news |first = Bob |last = Egelko |first2 = Kevin |last2 = Fagan |title = Man scales S.F. tower to publicize his message |url = http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Man-scales-S-F-tower-to-publicize-his-message-3175821.php |work = San Francisco Chronicle |date = September 7, 2010 |access-date = September 29, 2016 }} In 2013, the building sold its final unit, generating US$750 million in total sales, a 25 percent return on the estimated US$600 million in development costs.{{cite news |url = http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/print-edition/2013/04/05/millennium-tower-in-san-francisco-is.html |title = Millennium Tower in San Francisco is a $750M sellout |newspaper = San Francisco Business Times |first = J. K. |last = Dineen |date = April 5, 2013 |access-date = April 6, 2013 }} ==Sinking and tilting problem== [[File:Millennium tower and construction in SF 10.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Transbay Transit Center|TTC]] construction next to the tower]] After developers apparently disclosed in 2015 that the building was sinking and tilting, the public was notified of the problem in 2016. Treadwell & Rollo's geotechnical design for the foundation of the main tower consists of a concrete slab built on {{convert|60|–|90|ft|m|adj=mid|-deep}} [[Deep foundation#Driven foundations|concrete friction piles]] through the fill and [[young bay mud]], and embedded into dense [[Colma Formation|Colma]] sand. A number of other buildings in 301 Mission Street’s area have used similar systems, although due to varying earth conditions, others have pushed piles directly into the [[bedrock]] {{convert|200|ft|m}} below.{{cite web |last1 = Associated |first1 = Press |title = Leaning San Francisco tower seen sinking from space |url = http://www.foxnews.com/us/2016/11/28/leaning-san-francisco-tower-seen-sinking-from-space.html |publisher = [[Fox News]] |access-date = November 29, 2016 }}{{cite web |url = https://wolfstreet.com/2016/10/04/condo-owners-leaning-tower-of-san-francisco-knock-value-to-zero-millennium-tower/ |title = Owners at “Leaning Tower of San Francisco” Knock Condo Values to Zero |date = October 4, 2016 |website = Wolf Street }} An examination in 2016 showed the building had sunk {{convert|16|in|cm}} with a {{convert|2|in|cm|adj=on|spell=in}} tilt at the base and an approximate {{convert|6|in|cm|adj=on|spell=in}} tilt at the top of the tower.{{cite magazine |last1 = Smiley |first1 = Lauren |last2 = Eskenazi |first2 = Joe |title = The Big Sink |magazine = San Francisco Magazine |date = October 21, 2016 |url = http://modernluxury.com/san-francisco/story/the-big-sink |access-date = October 24, 2016 }} The building is leaning toward the northwest,{{cite news |last = Gecker |first = Jocelyn |url = http://abcnews.go.com/US/wireStory/tilting-sinking-san-francisco-high-rise-raises-alarm-43006857 |title = Tilting, Sinking San Francisco High-Rise Raises Alarm |publisher = [[ABC News]] |agency = [[Associated Press]] |date = October 24, 2016 |access-date = October 24, 2016 }}{{Cite news |first = Phillip |last = Matier |first2 = Andrew |last2 = Ross |date = August 1, 2016 |newspaper = San Francisco Chronicle |url = http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/SF-s-landmark-tower-for-rich-and-famous-is-8896563.php?t=1ef0887a20 |title = SF's landmark tower for rich and famous is sinking and tilting |access-date = August 2, 2016 }} and has caused cracks in the building's basement and the pavement surrounding the tower.{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/sep/06/large-crack-in-san-francisco-millennium-tower-window-is-latest-in-engineering-woes|title=San Francisco's sinking, leaning tower adds cracked window to list of woes|last=Wong|first=Julia Carrie|date=2018-09-06|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-09-27}} As of 2018, the sinking has increased to 18 inches with a lean of 14 inches.{{Cite web|url=https://www.sfchronicle.com/bayarea/article/Why-sinking-SF-tower-is-now-a-top-tourist-13231133.php|title=Why San Francisco's sinking Millennium Tower is now a top tourist destination|last=King|first=John|date=2018-09-15|website=San Francisco Chronicle|language=en}} The developer blames the sinking problem on the [[Transbay Joint Powers Authority]] (TJPA), who were responsible for construction of the neighboring [[Transbay Transit Center]] (TTC). However, the sinking problem had reportedly started before TTC construction even broke ground, and TJPA asserted the building had already settled {{convert|10|in|cm}}, well past the original maximum vertical settling prediction of {{convert|5.5|in|cm}} in 20 years, by the time TJPA began removing the timber piles under the prior [[Transbay Terminal]] in 2011.{{cite press release |url = http://www.transbaycenter.org/uploads/2016/09/TJPA-Press-Statement-Millennium-Towers-Sept-20-2016.pdf |title = Evidence does not support Millennium Partners' claim that the TJPA's dewatering is the cause of the excessive vertical settlement and tilting of the Millennium Tower |last = Boule |first = Scott |date = September 20, 2016 |publisher = Transbay Joint Powers Authority |access-date = June 15, 2017 }} The building's homeowners association, represented by general counsel Adrian Adams of Adams Stirling PLC, retained Dan Petrocelli of O’Melveny & Myers, to sue Webcor, Millennium Partners, and the TJPA.Dorsey, Matt. [https://www.omm.com/our-firm/media-center/press-releases/millennium-tower-homeowners-tap-petrocelli-as-lead-counsel/?sc_lang=en “Millennium Tower Homeowners Tap Petrocelli as Lead Counsel, Rounding Out All-Star Legal Team Prior to Lawsuit”], ‘’O’Melveny & Meyers Press Release’’, San Francisco, February 7, 2017. Retrieved August 18, 2017. Originally, the homeowners association had hired David Casselman to sue the TJPA instead of developer Millennium Partners, as Casselman noted that "inverse condemnation law allows residents to collect legal fees on top of any award, whereas suing the developer will steer up to 40 percent of any award to lawyers". Another group of tenants who disagree with the homeowners association, led by resident and patent litigator Jerry Dodson, is suing Millennium Partners, the City of San Francisco, and the TJPA.{{cite news |last1 = Tarmy |first1 = James |last2 = Mehrotra |first2 = Kartikay |title = Who Will Pay for San Francisco's $750 Million Tilting Tower? |url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-02-01/who-will-pay-for-san-francisco-s-tilting-sinking-millennium-tower |access-date = February 2, 2017 |work = Bloomberg Pursuits |publisher = Bloomberg |date = February 1, 2017 }} In breaking with Casselman and the homeowners association, Dodson has regarded Millennium Partners as the responsible culprit. In November 2016, the city of San Francisco filed suit against the tower's developer Mission Street Developers LLC, claiming that the developers withheld information on the sinking problems from potential apartment buyers.{{cite web |last1 = Dineen |first1 = J. K. |title = City attorney sues Millennium developer—says buyers duped |url = http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/City-attorney-sues-Millennium-developer-says-10591174.php |newspaper = San Francisco Chronicle |access-date = November 3, 2016 }}{{cite web |last1 = Skinner |first1 = Curtis |title = San Francisco city attorney sues developer of sinking luxury tower |url = https://www.reuters.com/article/us-california-tower-idUSKBN12Y2JV |website = Reuters |access-date = November 3, 2016 }} Mission Street Developers rejected the city's claims.{{cite news |first = Joseph |last = Serna |author2 = Peter H. King |date = November 3, 2016 |title = San Francisco sues developer over sinking skyscraper |url = http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-sinking-skyscraper-20161103-story.html |newspaper = Los Angeles Times |access-date = November 3, 2016 }} Sage Engineers has been hired by Millennium Partners to provide an engineering study on the sinking problem. Some experts have prognosticated that the cost to fix the tilt could exceed the liability insurance held by Millennium Partners and the building's various construction vendors. If the TJPA is found to be at fault, San Francisco taxpayers could end up paying for the repairs. {{As of|2017}}, a city inspection has found that the building is still safe to occupy, though there has been damage to the foundation and electrical system.{{cite news |last1 = Dineen |first1 = J. K. |title = Sinking Millennium Tower safe to live in, city report concludes |url = http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Sinking-Millennium-Tower-safe-to-live-in-city-10890276.php |access-date = February 2, 2017 |work = San Francisco Chronicle |date = January 27, 2017 }} In March 2017, the homeowners association filed suit against Millennium Partners, Webcor, Handel Architects, Treadwell & Rollo, Langan, DeSimone Consulting Engineers, Arup, and Transbay Joint Powers Authority. They are seeking $200 million to cover repairs and damages.{{Cite news |url = http://news.buzzbuzzhome.com/2017/04/millennium-tower-sf-homeowners-lawsuit.html |title = Millennium Tower San Francisco homeowners strike back with $200 million lawsuit |date = April 5, 2017 |work = BuzzBuzzHome News |access-date = April 18, 2017 |language = en-US }} In early September 2018, residents reported hearing various "creaking sounds". At around 2:30 a.m. on the morning of Saturday, September 8, 2018, residents reported hearing a loud "popping sound". On Sunday, the following day, a resident located in a corner unit on the 36th floor discovered a cracked window. The glass used in the building's windows and facade is rated to withstand hurricane force winds, leading to concern that the crack was a symptom of a much larger structural failure.[https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Millennium-Tower-s-managers-say-cracked-window-13213528.php?t=3ed01f73e2 Millennium Tower window crack could signal bigger problem, report says]. ''San Francisco Chronicle'', September 7, 2018 On October 2, 2018 after an investigation by an architectural engineering firm hired by the homeowners association, it was announced that the cracked window was caused by an "exterior impact" and not related to the building sinking and movement.https://media.nbcbayarea.com/documents/MTcoverletter+100218.pdf ==Awards== The building has garnered several awards from several engineering and architectural organisations.{{Structurae|s0031184}} * 2008: American Concrete Institute Awards, Northern California – Construction * 2008: Concrete Industry Board – Roger H. CIB Award of Merit * 2009: American Society of Civil Engineers, Region 9 – Structural Engineering Project of the Year * 2008: American Society of Civil Engineers, San Francisco Section – Outstanding Structural Engineering Project * 2009: Metal Architecture Magazine – April 2009 edition Top Honor * 2009: California Construction – Outstanding Project Management * 2009: California Construction – Multi-family/Residential, Award of Merit * 2010: ''San Francisco Business Times'' – Deal of the Year Award * 2010: San Francisco Chamber of Commerce Excellence in Business Awards – Building San Francisco Award ==Notable residents== * [[Joe Montana]]{{cite news |last = Whiting |first = Sam |title = Joe Montana finds empty nest in San Francisco |url = http://www.sfgate.com/49ers/article/Joe-Montana-finds-empty-nest-in-San-Francisco-3182342.php |newspaper = San Francisco Chronicle |date = July 6, 2010 |access-date = April 7, 2012 }} * [[Hunter Pence]] * [[Kevin Durant]] * [[Craig Ramsey]]{{cite web |url = https://sf.curbed.com/2016/12/16/13987094/millennium-tower-penthouse-record-sale |title = Millennium Tower breaks record, nets $13 million for penthouse |first = Brock |last = Keeling |date = December 16, 2016 |website = Curbed SF }} * [[Thomas Perkins (businessman)|Tom Perkins]]{{cite web |url = https://www.wsj.com/articles/tom-perkinss-penthouse-in-sinking-millennium-tower-sells-1481909864 |title = Tom Perkins’s Penthouse in Sinking Millennium Tower Sells |first = Candace |last = Taylor |date = December 16, 2016 |publisher = The Wall Street Journal |via = www.wsj.com }} *[[Drew Houston]] ==Gallery== file:Millennium Tower, SF, under construction in June 2006.JPG|Early June 2006 file:Millennium Tower (301 Mission Street) SF under construction, showing the crane footing, concrete core and construction equipment. The Transbay Terminal is visible to the left.JPG|August 16 file:The Millennium Tower (301 Mission Street) construction site.JPG|Late October file:The Millennium Tower (301 Mission Street) construction as seen from Mission Street, SF, May 2007.JPG|May 2007 file:The Millennium Tower (301 Mission Street) rising out of the South of Market skyline, SF.JPG|Mid-July 2007 file:Img3330SeptemberMillenniumTower.JPG|September 2007 file:MilleneumTowerUnderConstructionDuringFebruary2008.jpg|February 2008 file:The Millennium Tower (301 Mission Street) as seen from the south, SF, March 2008.JPG|March 2008 File:Millennium Tower, San Francisco, Sign.jpg|Millennium Tower sign on the South facade ==See also== *[[List of tallest buildings in San Francisco]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons Category|Millennium Tower (San Francisco, California)}} * {{Official website|www.millenniumtowersf.com}} {{Buildings in San Francisco|state=collapsed}} {{Portal bar|San Francisco Bay Area}} [[Category:Residential buildings completed in 2009]] [[Category:Residential skyscrapers in San Francisco]] [[Category:Residential condominiums in San Francisco]] [[Category:South of Market, San Francisco]] [[Category:2009 in San Francisco]] [[Category:2009 establishments in California]] [[Category:2016 in San Francisco]] [[Category:Engineering failures]] [[Category:Inclined towers in the United States]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/2A02:587:3A09:4500:2898:EEEF:1C0C:F2F0|2A02:587:3A09:4500:2898:EEEF:1C0C:F2F0]] ([[User talk:2A02:587:3A09:4500:2898:EEEF:1C0C:F2F0|talk]]) to last revision by AnomieBOT. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Redirect|Eastern Germany}} {{For|the country that existed from 1949 until 1990|East Germany}} {{New federal states labelled map}} {{History of Germany|expanded=Contemporary}} The '''new federal states of Germany''' ({{lang-de|die neuen Bundesländer}}) are the five re-established [[States of Germany|states]] in the former [[East Germany]] that acceded to the [[Federal Republic of Germany]] with its [[Old states of Germany|10 states]] upon [[German reunification]] on 3 October 1990.
The new states, which [[East German Administrative Reform of 1952|were dissolved]] by the [[Government of East Germany|East German government]] in 1952 and were re-established in 1990, are [[Brandenburg]], [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]], [[Saxony]], [[Saxony-Anhalt]] and [[Thuringia]]. The state of [[Berlin]], the result of a merger between [[East Berlin|East]] and [[West Berlin]], is usually not considered one of the new states, although many of its residents are former East Germans.
Since the reunification, Germany thus consists of 16 states with equal legal statuses. Yet the process of the "[[inner reunification]]" between the former East and West Germany is still ongoing.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}}
==Culture== {{See also|Ostalgie}} [[File:Ampelmaenner.jpg|thumb|The [[Ampelmännchen]], symbol of the East German culture]] Persisting differences in culture and mentality among the old [[East Germany]] and old [[West Germany]] are often referred to as the "wall in the head" ("Mauer im Kopf").<ref name="dw1004">{{Cite web|author= |title=Breaking Down the Wall in the Head |url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,1564,1344803,00.html |work= |publisher=[[Deutsche Welle]] |date=2004-10-03 |accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref> "Ossis" ("Easties") are stereotyped as racist, poor and largely influenced by [[Russia]]n culture.<ref>{{Cite web |author=Cameron Abadi |title=The Berlin fall |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2009/06/18/the_berlin_fall?page=0,2 |work= |publisher=Foreign Policy |date=2009-08-07 |accessdate=2009-10-11 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090809203430/http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2009/06/18/the_berlin_fall?page=0,2 |archive-date=2009-08-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> "[[Wessi]]s" ("Westies") are usually considered snobbish, dishonest, wealthy, and selfish. The terms can be considered disparaging.
In 2009, twenty years after the fall of the wall, a poll found that 22% of former East Germans (40% of under-25s) considered themselves "real citizens of the Federal Republic".<ref name="bz"/> 62% feel in a kind of limbo, no longer citizens of East Germany but not fully integrated into the unified Germany. Around 11% would have liked to have East Germany back.<ref name="bz">{{Cite web|author= |title=Noch nicht angekommen - Survey of 2900 adults in the New Länder in summer 2008 |url=http://www.berlinonline.de/berliner-zeitung/archiv/.bin/dump.fcgi/2009/0121/politik/0022/index.html |work= |publisher=Berliner Zeitung |date=21 January 2009 |accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref> A 2004 poll found that 25% of West Germans and 12% of East Germans wished reunification had not happened.<ref name="dw1004"/>
Some East German brands have been revived, appealing to former East Germans who are nostalgic for the goods they grew up with.<ref name="dw1003"/> Brands revived in this manner include [[:de:Rotkäppchen Sektkellerei|Rotkäppchen]], which holds about 40% of the German sparkling wine market, and [[:de:Zeha Schuhfabrik Hohenleuben|Zeha]], the sport shoe maker that supplied most of East Germany's sports teams and also the [[Soviet Union national football team]].<ref name="dw1003">{{Cite web|author= |title=East German brands thrive 20 years after end of Communism |url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,4752593,00.html |work= |publisher=Deutsche Welle |date=2009-10-03 |accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref>
[[Pornography]] and [[prostitution]] were outlawed in the GDR as forms of exploitation, and West Germans commonly believe that those who grew up in the GDR are more sexually inhibited than their western counterparts. Nonetheless, better access to higher education and jobs along with free abortion, contraception and generous family policies made East German women generally more promiscuous with respect to their sex life.<ref name="tel">{{cite news |author= |title='Women's love lives were better in East Germany before the Berlin Wall fell' |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/expat/expatnews/6373531/Womens-love-lives-were-better-in-East-Germany-before-the-Berlin-Wall-fell.html |work= |publisher=Telegraph |date=2009-10-19 |accessdate=2009-10-11 | location=London | first=Etienne | last=Balmer}}</ref> Another notable difference is the attitude towards [[naturism]] or FKK (short for ''[[Freikörperkultur]]'') in German. While it existed in both East and West, only in the East was it a mass cultural phenomenon in which almost everybody participated. This can still be seen at beaches of former East Germany compared to their West German counterparts.
More children are born out of wedlock in eastern Germany than in western Germany. In 2009, in eastern Germany 61% of births were to unmarried women, while in western Germany 27% were. The states of Saxony-Anhalt and Mecklenburg-Western Pomerania had the highest rate of birth outside wedlock, each with 64%, followed by Brandenburg with 62%. The state of Baden-Württemberg had the lowest rate with 22%, followed by Hesse and Bavaria, each with 26%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thelocal.de/society/20110812-36923.html#.UTLa0Dcce0Q|title=One third of children born out of wedlock|date=12 August 2011|publisher=}}</ref>
===Religion=== {{See also|State atheism|Christianity in East Germany}} {{Pie chart |thumb = right |caption = Religion in East Germany with East Berlin (2016)<ref name="Politbarometer 2016 Bundesland" /> |label1 = [[Agnosticist]]s/[[Atheist]]s |value1 = 68.2 |color1 = Honeydew |label2 = [[Protestant]]s |value2 = 24.1 |color2 = DodgerBlue |label3 = [[Catholic Church|Catholics]] |value3 = 5.2 |color3 = DarkOrchid |label4 = [[Islam|Muslims]] |value4 = 0.3 |color4 = Green |label5 = [[Judaism]] |value5 = 0.1 |color5 = DarkBlue |label6 = Other religion |value6 = 1.3 |color6 = Chartreuse |label7 = Not declared and unknown |value7 = 0.8 |color7 = Black }} [[Irreligion]] is predominant in the eastern part of Germany, which is considered to be the least religious region in the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.focus.de/politik/videos/ostdeutschland-hochburg-der-atheisten-als-pfarrer-in-einer-der-gottlosesten-regionen-der-welt_vid_33747.html|title=Ostdeutschland: Wo der Atheist zu Hause ist|year=2012|publisher=[[Focus (German magazine)|''Focus'']]|accessdate=2017-11-11}}</ref><ref name="godless2">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcrunch.com/why-eastern-germany-most-godless-place-planet/culture-society/why-eastern-germany-is-the-most-godless-place-on-earth/c3s5177#.UHNiqk3Ex_0|title=WHY EASTERN GERMANY IS THE MOST GODLESS PLACE ON EARTH|year=2012|publisher=''[[Die Welt]]''|accessdate=2009-05-24|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6EW1MbdrZ?url=http://www.worldcrunch.com/why-eastern-germany-most-godless-place-planet/culture-society/why-eastern-germany-is-the-most-godless-place-on-earth/c3s5177#.UHNiqk3Ex_0|archivedate=2013-02-18|df=}}</ref><ref name="atheistic2">{{cite web|url=http://www.dialoginternational.com/dialog_international/2012/05/east-germany-the-most-atheistic-of-any-region.html|title=East Germany the "most atheistic" of any region|year=2012|publisher=Dialog International|accessdate=2009-05-24}}</ref> An exception is former [[West Berlin]], which had a Christian plurality in 2016 (44.4% Christian and 43.5% unaffiliated). It also has a higher share of Muslims, at 8.5%, compared to former [[East Berlin]] with only 1.5% self-declared Muslims as of 2016.<ref name="Politbarometer 2016 Bundesland">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=2016|title=Konfession, Bundesland - weighted (Kumulierter Datensatz)|url=http://zacat.gesis.org/webview/index.jsp?headers=http%3A%2F%2F193.175.238.79%3A80%2Fobj%2FfVariable%2FZA6888_V313&stubs=http%3A%2F%2F193.175.238.79%3A80%2Fobj%2FfVariable%2FZA6888_V7&previousmode=table&sort=column&byc=2&study=http%3A%2F%2F193.175.238.79%3A80%2Fobj%2FfStudy%2FZA6888&charttype=null&by=1&mode=table&v=2&V313slice=1&V7slice=12&order=asc&weights=http%3A%2F%2F193.175.238.79%3A80%2Fobj%2FfVariable%2FZA6888_V319&weights=http%3A%2F%2F193.175.238.79%3A80%2Fobj%2FfVariable%2FZA6888_V320&analysismode=table&gs=5&tabcontenttype=row&top=yes|journal=Politbarometer 2016|volume=|pages=Question V312.F1|via=[[GESIS – Leibniz Institute for the Social Sciences|GESIS]]}}</ref> On the other hand, Christianity is the dominant religion of [[Western Germany]], excluding [[Hamburg]], which has a non-religious plurality. {| class="sortable wikitable" style="margin:auto" !Religion by state, 2016<ref name="Politbarometer 2016 Bundesland" /> !Protestants !Catholics !Not religious !Muslims !Others |- style="background: #eee" |{{flagicon|Brandenburg}} [[Brandenburg]] |24.9% |3.5% |'''69.9%''' |0.0% |1.5% |- style="background: #eee" |{{flagicon|Berlin}} former [[East Berlin]] |14.3% |7.5% |'''74.3%''' |1.5% |2.4% |- style="background: #eee" |{{flagicon|Mecklenburg-Vorpommern}} [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]] |24.9% |3.9% |'''70.0%''' |0.3% |0.9% |- style="background: #eee" |{{flagicon|Saxony}} [[Saxony]] |27.6% |4.0% |'''66.9%''' |0.3% |1.1% |- style="background: #eee" |{{flagicon|Saxony-Anhalt}} [[Saxony-Anhalt]] |18.8% |5.1% |'''74.7%''' |0.3% |1.2% |- style="background: #eee" |{{flagicon|Thuringia}} [[Thuringia]] |27.8% |9.5% |'''61.2%''' |0.0% |1.5% |- !Total !24.3% !5.2% !68.8% !0.3% !1.4% |}
====Pro Reli==== On 26 April 2009, a referendum ([[:de:Volksentscheid über die Einführung des Wahlpflichtbereichs Ethik/Religion|de]]) was held on whether Berlin pupils should be allowed to choose between the ethics class, a compulsory class introduced in all Berlin schools in 2006, and a religion class.<ref name="Verbij">{{Cite news |url=https://www.trouw.nl/home/berlijn-blijft-een-heidense-stad~a6c1bb85/ |title=Berlijn blijft een heidense stad |author=Antoine Verbij |work=[[Trouw]] |date=27 April 2009 |accessdate=24 January 2018 |language=nl}}</ref> The SPD, the Left Party and Greens supported the "Pro Ethics" camp for a "No" vote, stressing that the ethics class should remain compulsory, and pupils could voluntarily take an extra religion class alongside it if they so chose; the CDU and FDP supported the "Pro Reli" camp for a "Yes" vote, wanting to give pupils a free choice.<ref name="Verbij"/> In East Berlin, an overwhelming majority<ref name="Verbij"/> of 74.62%{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} voted against the introduction of religious education. In West Berlin, only 41.41% voted "No".{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} In total, 51.5% voted "No" and 48.4% voted "Yes".<ref name="Verbij"/>
==Economy== {{See also|Economy of Germany}} [[File:Block Poehoe alt.jpg|thumb|left|DDR-era [[plattenbau|apartment blocks]] in [[Ilmenau]], [[Thuringia]]]] The [[economic reconstruction]] of eastern Germany ({{lang-de|Aufbau Ost}}) is proving to be longer-term than originally foreseen.<ref name="tatsachen"/> The [[standard of living]] and average annual income remain significantly lower in the new federal states.<ref name="FR">{{Cite web|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |title=The Price of a Failed Reunification |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/spiegel/0,1518,373639,00.html |work= |publisher=Spiegel International |date=2005-09-05 |accessdate=2006-11-28}}</ref>
Reunification cost the federal government [[€]]2 [[Orders of magnitude (numbers)#1012|trillion]].<ref name="tol0807"/> At reunification, almost all East German industry was considered outdated.<ref name="tatsachen">{{Cite web|author= |title=Aufbau Ost, economic reconstruction in the East |url=http://www.tatsachen-ueber-deutschland.de/en/economy/content/background/aufbau-ost-economic-reconstruction-in-the-east.html?type=1 |work= |publisher=Deutsche Bundesregierung |date=2007-08-24 |accessdate=2009-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091001213355/http://www.tatsachen-ueber-deutschland.de/en/economy/content/background/aufbau-ost-economic-reconstruction-in-the-east.html?type=1 |archivedate=October 1, 2009 }}</ref> The government privatised 8,500 state-owned East German enterprises.<ref name="tol0807"/> Since 1990, between €100 billion and €140 billion a year have been transferred to the new states.<ref name="tol0807">{{cite news |author= |title=Germany starts recovery from €2,000bn union |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article2317382.ece|work= |publisher=Times Online |date=2007-08-24 |accessdate=2009-10-12 | location=London | first=Roger | last=Boyes}}</ref> More than $60 billion were spent supporting businesses and building infrastructure in the years 2006-2008.<ref name="nyt0609">{{cite news |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |title=In East Germany, a Decline as Stark as a Wall |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/19/world/europe/19germany.html |work= |publisher=New York Times |date= 2009-06-19|accessdate=October 11, 2009 | first=Nicholas | last=Kulish}}</ref>
A €156 billion [[economic plan]], Solidarity Pact II, came into force in 2005, and provides the financial basis for the advancement and special promotion of the economy of the new federal states until 2019.<ref name="tatsachen"/> The "solidarity tax", a 5.5% surcharge on the income tax, was instated by the [[Helmut Kohl|Kohl government]] to restore the infrastructure of the new states to the levels of the western ones<ref name="ind">{{cite news |author= |title=Calls grow to lift burden of Germany's solidarity tax |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/calls-grow-to-lift-burden-of-germanys-solidarity-tax-459805.html |work= |publisher=The Independent |date=2007-08-01 |accessdate=2009-10-12 | location=London | first=Allan | last=Hall}}</ref> and to apportion the cost of unification as well as the expenses of the Gulf War and of European integration. The tax, which raises €11 billion a year, will be maintained until 2019 at least.<ref name="ind"/>
Ever since reunification, the unemployment rate in the east has been almost twice that of the west. The unemployment rate reached 12.7%<ref name="Statistics Bundesagentur für Arbeit">{{cite web|url=http://statistik.arbeitsagentur.de/statistik/index.php?id=WO|title=Current statistics of the Bundesagentur für Arbeit comparing east and west|publisher=|access-date=2010-05-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100523085536/http://statistik.arbeitsagentur.de/statistik/index.php?id=WO|archive-date=2010-05-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> in April 2010, after having reached a maximum of 18.7% in 2005. In the decade 1999-2009, economic activity per person has risen from 67% to 71% of western Germany.<ref name="nyt0609"/> According to [[Wolfgang Tiefensee]], the minister then responsible for the development of the new federal states, in 2009, "The gap is closing."<ref name="nyt0609"/> Eastern Germany is also the part of the country least affected by the [[Financial crisis of 2007–08|2007-2008 financial crisis]].<ref>{{Cite web|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |title=Eastern Germany Less Hard Hit than the West |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/0,1518,629662,00.html |work= |publisher=Spiegel International |date= |accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref>
All the new federal states, excluding [[Berlin]], qualify as ''[[Regional policy of the European Union#Objective One|Objective 1]]'' development regions within the [[European Union]], and are eligible to receive [[European Regional Development Fund|investment subsidies]] of up to 30% until 2013.{{update inline|date=March 2014}}
==Infrastructure== The "German Unity Transport Projects" ([[:de:Verkehrsprojekte Deutsche Einheit|Verkehrsprojekte Deutsche Einheit]], VDE) is a programme launched in 1991 and meant to upgrade the infrastructure of eastern Germany, and modernise transport links between the old and new federal states.<ref name="fgc">{{Cite web|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |title=Infrastructure for unified Germany |url=http://www.bmvbs.de/en/Federal-Government-Commissione/-,2577/Infrastructure-for-unified-Ger.htm |work= |publisher=Federal Government Commissioner for the New Federal States |date= |accessdate=2009-10-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090915215944/http://www.bmvbs.de/en/Federal-Government-Commissione/-,2577/Infrastructure-for-unified-Ger.htm |archivedate=September 15, 2009 }}</ref>
The programme consists of nine railway and seven motorway projects, as well as one [[waterway]] project, with a total funding of €38.5 billion. As of 2009, all 17 projects are either under construction or have already been completed.<ref name="unece">{{Cite web|last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |title=Draft Federal Transport Infrastructure Plan |url=http://www.unece.org/trans/doc/transsitdocs/Germany%20-%20Transport%20infrastructure%20plan.pdf |work= |publisher=United Nations Economic Commission for Europe |date= |accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref> The construction of new railway lines and high-speed upgrades of existing lines reduced journey times between Berlin and [[Hanover]] from over four hours to 96 minutes.<ref name="fgc"/> Due to increasing car usage and depopulation since reunification, many railway lines (branches and main lines) have been closed by the unified [[Deutsche Bahn]] (German Railways). Some main lines are still not finished or upgraded according to the VDE, with the Leipzig-Nuremberg line (via Erfurt and part of the Munich-Berlin route) scheduled to come on-line in December 2017, almost three decades after reunification. Some lines, even those connecting large cities, are still in a worse state then they were in the 1930s, with travel time from Berlin to Dresden slower in 2015 than in 1935.
"DEGES" (''Deutsche Einheit Fernstraßenplanungs- und -bau GmbH'', German Unity Road Construction Company) is the state-owned project management institution responsible for the construction of approximately 1,360 km of federal roads within the VDE, with a total investment of €10.2 billion. It is also involved in other transport projects, including 435 km of roads costing about €1,760 million as well as a city tunnel in [[Leipzig]], at the cost of €685 million.<ref>{{Cite web|last1=|first1=|last2=|first2=|title=Firmenprofil|url=http://www.deges.de/deges.html|work=|publisher=DEGES|date=|accessdate=2009-10-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090525090448/http://deges.de/deges.html|archivedate=2009-05-25|df=}}</ref>
The Federal Transport Infrastructure Plan 2003 includes plans for the extension of the [[Bundesautobahn 14|A14 motorway]] from [[Magdeburg]] to [[Schwerin]] and construction of the [[Bundesautobahn 72|A72]] from [[Chemnitz]] to [[Leipzig]].<ref name="unece"/>
Private ownership rates of cars have markedly increased since 1990: in 1988, 55% of East German households had at least one car, in 1993 this had already risen to 67%, and to 71% in 1998. This compares to the West German rates of 61% in 1988, 74% in 1993 and 76% in 1998.<ref>[http://www.wz-berlin.de/publikation/pdf/mit91/wzbmit91-31-35.pdf Wilhelm Hinrichs: ''Die Ostdeutschen in Bewegung – Formen und Ausmaß regionaler Mobilität in den neuen Bundesländern''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040829002111/http://www.wz-berlin.de/publikation/pdf/mit91/wzbmit91-31-35.pdf |date=2004-08-29 }} (PDF-Dokument)</ref><ref>[http://www.bpb.de/publikationen/05049451825358354051911907431409,2,0,Die_DDR_in_den_siebziger_Jahren.html bpb: Bundeszentrale für politische Bildung: ''Die DDR in den siebziger Jahren'']</ref>
==Politics== {{Undue weight|section|date=October 2009}} Unlike the West, there was a three-party system (SPD, CDU, PDS/The Left) until the rise of the AfD,<ref name="Schoon 9">Steffen Schoon: ''Wählerverhalten und Strukturmuster des Parteienwettbewerbs'', in: Steffen Schoon, Nikolaus Werz (Hrsg.): ''Die Landtagswahl in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern 2006'', Rostock 2006, S. 9.</ref><ref>http://www.kai-arzheimer.com/wahlforschung/vl-wve-08-screen.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.lotharprobst.de/fileadmin/user_upload/redakteur/Publikationen/Ostdeutsches%20Parteiensystem%20und%20Entwicklung%20der%20Gruenen.pdf.</ref> which has led to a four-party system.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wiwo.de/politik/deutschland/landtagswahlen-2016-afd-wird-ost-volkspartei-fdp-laeuft-sich-fuer-bundestag-warm/13315598.html|title=Landtagswahlen 2016: AfD wird Ost-Volkspartei, FDP läuft sich für Bundestag warm|website=www.wiwo.de}}</ref> Since 2009 at least four factions have been represented in each of the East German regional parliaments, in Saxony even six, while in 1998/1999, for example, only one of the regional parliaments included more than three factions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bpb.de/geschichte/zeitgeschichte/deutschlandarchiv/202315/parteien-und-parteienwettbewerb-in-west-und-ostdeutschland|title=Parteien und Parteienwettbewerb in West- und Ostdeutschland - bpb|first=Bundeszentrale für politische|last=Bildung|website=www.bpb.de}}</ref>
In the East, there is usually a low turnout at elections.
The East German Länder have - with the exception of the regional conference of the heads of government of the East German states (MPK-Ost)<ref>[http://www.ministerpraesident.sachsen.de/19116.htm ''Regionalkonferenz der Regierungschefin und der Regierungschefs der ostdeutschen Länder (MPK-Ost)''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120702210847/http://www.ministerpraesident.sachsen.de/19116.htm |date=2012-07-02 }}, Webseite der Sächsischen Staatskanzlei (Ministerpräsident). Abgerufen am 18. April 2013.</ref> - no joint state or public representation.
While "only" 56% want better relations with Russia in the West, 66% of the population of the former Soviet satellite state want better relations with Russia after 28 years (and above all the stronger parties in the East: AfD 74% and the Left 71%).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.epochtimes.de/politik/deutschland/umfrage-mehrheit-der-deutschen-will-bessere-beziehungen-zu-russland-a2252432.html|title=Umfrage: Mehrheit der Deutschen will bessere Beziehungen zu Russland|first=|last=EpochTimes.de|date=28 October 2017|publisher=}}</ref>
===Far left=== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 150 | image1 = Karte der Reichstagswahlen 1912 en.png | caption1 = Map of German Reichstag election 1912. (Good example of Social Democrats (SPD)) | image2 = Reichstagswahl 1920.svg | caption2 = Results of the Reichstag election 1920 (Good example of Independent Socialists (USPD)) | image3 = KPD Wahl 1933.svg | caption3 = Communists (KPD) | footer = Even before the German division, the east was a high-rise of left-wing and Far-left parties. }} The socialist party [[The Left (Germany)|The Left]] (''Die Linke'', successor to the ''Party of Democratic Socialism'', the [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany|GDR state party]]'s successor) has been successful throughout eastern Germany, perhaps as a result of the continued disparity of living conditions and salaries compared with western Germany, and high unemployment.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://die-linke.de/wahlen/positionen/themen_az/io/ostdeutschland/| title=DIE LINKE: Ostdeutschland}}</ref> Since its association with the [[Labour and Social Justice – The Electoral Alternative|WASG]], The Left mostly loses in state elections, and has been losing members since 2010.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/austritte-und-nachwuchsprobleme-linke-verliert-massiv-mitglieder/5864836.html| title=Linke verliert massiv Mitglieder}}</ref>
Historically, in the German Empire and the Weimar Republic the strongholds of the [[SPD]], [[USPD]] and [[KPD]] were Thuringia, Brandenburg, Berlin, Saxony-Anhalt and Saxony.
The [[Party of Democratic Socialism (Germany)|Party of Democratic Socialism]] (PDS), and The Left from 2005, have achieved the following vote shares in recent elections: {| class="wikitable" |- !Election !Vote percentages |- |[[East German general election, 1990]] | 16.4%, [[Communist Party of Germany (1990)|Communist Party of Germany]] (KPD) 0.1% |- |[[German federal election, 1990]] | East 11.1%, West 0.2% |- |State elections, 1990 |East Berlin 30.1%, KPD 0.2%; Mecklenburg-Vorpommern 15.7%; Saxony 10.2%; Saxony-Anhalt 12.0%; Thuringia 9.7%; East Berlin 23.6% |- |[[German federal election, 1994|Federal election, 1994]] | East 19.8%, West 1% |- |State elections in 1994: |18.7% in Brandenburg; 19.9% in Saxony-Anhalt; Saxony 16.5%; Thuringia 16.6%; 22.7% in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern |- |Berlin state election, 1995 |in East Berlin the PDS was the biggest party with 36.3%. |- |[[German federal election, 1998|Federal election, 1998]] | East 21.6%, West 1.2%. |- |State elections in 1998/1999: |23.3% in [[Brandenburg state election, 1999|Brandenburg]]; 19.6% in Saxony-Anhalt; Saxony 22.2%, KPD 0.1%; Thuringia 21.3%; 24.4% in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern; 39.5% in East Berlin. |- |[[German federal election, 2002|Federal election, 2002]] | East 16.9%, West 1.1% |- |State elections in 2001/2002 | 16.4% in [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern state election, 2002|Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]]; 20.4%, KPD/DKP 0.1% in [[Saxony-Anhalt state election, 2002|Saxony-Anhalt]]; 47.6%, 0.2% DKP in [[Berlin state election, 2001|East Berlin]]. |- |[[German federal election, 2005|Federal election, 2005]] | East 25.3%, West 4.9% |- |State elections in 2004 to 2006 | 16.8% in [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern state election, 2006|Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]] (+0.5% WASG), 24.1% in [[Saxony-Anhalt state election, 2006|Saxony-Anhalt]] and 28.1% (+3.3% WASG) in [[Berlin state election, 2006|East Berlin]] (–19.5%). |- |[[German federal election, 2009|Federal election, 2009]] | East 28.5% (The Left became the strongest force in Brandenburg and Saxony-Anhalt); West 7.4%. |} {{Graph:Chart|width=600|height=200|xAxisTitle=Results of The Left, DKP and KPD in the new states|yAxisTitle=%|legend=Legende|type=line |y1Title=Volkskammer/Bundestag |y2Title=East-Berlin |y3Title=Brandenburg |y4Title=Mecklenburg-Vorpommern |y5Title=Saxony |y6Title=Saxony-Anhalt |y7Title=Thuringia |y8Title=European Parliament |y9Title=Election threshold |colors=#ffff0000,#ff000000, #8b1c62, #ff008b00, #ff009ee0, #ffffff00, #FFAA4422, #FF043390, darkgray |xType=string |x= 1990a, 1990b, 1994/95, 1998/99, 2001/02, 2004/06, 2009/10, 2011/11, 2013/14, 2016/17, |y1= 16.5, 11.1, 19.8, 21.6, 16.9, 25.3, 28.5, 28.5, 22.7, 17.9, |y2= 30.2, 23.6, 36.3, 39.5, 47.8, 31.4, 31.4, 23.1, 23.1, 23.8, |y3= , 13.4, 18.7, 23.3, 23.3, 28.1, 27.3, 27.3, 18.8, 18.8, |y4= , 15.7, 22.7, 24.6, 16.4, 17.3, 17.3, 18.6, 18.6, 13.3, |y5= , 10.2, 16.5, 22.3, 22.3, 23.6, 18.9, 18.9, 18.9, 18.9, |y6= , 12.0, 19.9, 19.6, 20.5, 24.2, 24.2, 23.8, 23.8, 16.3, |y7= , 9.7, 16.6, 21.3, 21.3, 26.3, 27.4, 27.4, 28.3, 28.3, |y8= , , 20.6, 23.0, 23.0, 25.5, 23.4, 23.4, 20.9, 20.9, |y9= 5.0, , , , , , , , , 5.0, }}
Due to the loss of votes to the AfD, the Left plans to establish a regional group East.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.tagesschau.de/inland/linkspartei-bundestag-101.html|title=Nach der Bundestagswahl: Linkspartei will Protestwähler zurückholen|first=|last=tagesschau.de|website=tagesschau.de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rbb24.de/politik/beitrag/2017/10/linke-plant-landesgruppe-ost-im-bundestag.html|title=Landesgruppe Ost soll Protestwähler zurückholen|website=www.rbb24.de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.epochtimes.de/politik/deutschland/nach-afd-erfolg-linksfraktion-will-landesgruppe-ost-gruenden-a2234814.html|title=Nach AfD-Erfolg: Linksfraktion will "Landesgruppe Ost" gründen|first=|last=EpochTimes.de|date=7 October 2017|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.n-tv.de/politik/Linke-plant-Landesgruppe-Ost-im-Bundestag-article20070724.html|title=Linke plant Landesgruppe Ost im Bundestag|first=n-tv|last=Nachrichtenfernsehen|publisher=}}</ref>
===Far right=== {{expand section|[[Pegida]]|date=October 2017}} After 1990, far-right and [[German nationalist]] groups gained followers. Some sources{{Who|date=September 2010}} claim mostly among people frustrated by the high unemployment and the poor economic situation.<ref name="tol"/> ''[[Der Spiegel]]'' also points out that these people are mostly single men and that there may also be socio-demographic reasons.<ref name="sp07"/> Since around 1998 the Party stronghold moved from the south of Germany to the east.<ref>{{Cite web| url=https://interaktiv.morgenpost.de/wo-deutschland-rechts-waehlt|title=Es war nicht immer der Osten – Wo Deutschland rechts wählt}}/</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url=https://books.google.de/books?id=YRwdBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA321&lpg=PA321&dq=seit+1998+osten+rechts&source=bl&ots=eQAA51TSLc&sig=-ASAQy5bTcacyYvZw86XMr9VvSY&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiE8NiEj4bXAhXFfhoKHVl6ArM4ChDoAQgmMAA#v=onepage&q=seit%201998%20osten%20rechts&f=false|title=Deutschland nach den Wahlen: Befunde zur Bundestagswahl 1998 und zur Zukunft des deutschen Parteiensystems}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web| url=https://books.google.de/books?id=6hyU9XlxQAwC&pg=PA46&lpg=PA46&dq=wahlergebnisse+rechts+osten+1998&source=bl&ots=OxBkcpZtL3&sig=n_GJNRWP7gpyFgpSLfmximxsR94&hl=de&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiejr7dxobXAhXN0RoKHdP3CagQ6AEIcTAP#v=onepage&q=wahlergebnisse%20rechts%20osten%201998&f=false| title=Rechtsaußenparteien in Deutschland: Bedingungen ihres Erfolges und Scheiterns}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bpb.de/apuz/130415/rechtsextremismus-ein-ostdeutsches-phaenomen| title=Rechtsextremismus - ein ostdeutsches Phänomen?}}</ref>
Already in the German Empire and the Weimar Republic the strongholds of the [[German Conservative Party]] (DKP), [[German National People's Party]] (DNVP) and [[Nazi Party]] (NSDAP) they were Pomerania, Lower Silesia, East Prussia and Brandenburg. (Prussia)
The Far-right party [[German People's Union]] (DVU) was since [[Saxony-Anhalt state election, 1998|1998]] in Saxony-Anhalt and in Brandenburg sice [[Brandenburg state election, 1999|1999]]. A study of the University of Berlin from 1998/99 comes to 13% for the whole of Germany, and 12% for the West and 17% for the East for right-wing extremist recruitment potential.<ref>Nach Iris Huth: ''Politische Verdrossenheit'', Band 3, 2004, S. 226.</ref>
In May 2001, the Düsseldorf Federal Party Congress of the FDP decided the strategy, the "Strategy 18" which is premised by [[Jürgen Möllemann]] as a goal. Jürgen Möllemann stood behind Jamal Karsli who is criticized as anti-Semitic,<ref>[http://www.zentralratdjuden.de/de/article/194.html ''Möllemanns und Westerwelles unerträgliche Angriffe gegen Friedman''], Zentralrat der Juden in Deutschland, 22 May 2002.</ref> Möllemann was criticized by the then FDP leader [[Guido Westerwelle]] that he wanted to make the [[Free Democratic Party (Germany)|FDP]] a right-wing populist party<ref>{{Cite web| url=https://www.welt.de/print-welt/article273430/FDP-wirft-Moellemann-Rechtspopulismus-vor.html| title=FDP wirft Möllemann Rechtspopulismus vor}}</ref> and got the backing of [[Jörg Haider]].<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.faz.net/aktuell/politik/antisemitismus-streit-moellemann-bekommt-beifall-von-haider-160367.html| title=Möllemann bekommt Beifall von Haider}}</ref> The name referred to the election goal of tripling the share of electoral votes from 6 to 18%. In the midst of controversy over a possibly associated right-wing populist orientation, the FDP ultimately achieved 7.4% and moved away from the course after the election, but gained in all new states in [[German federal election, 2002|2002]] between 3.6% in Saxony and 2.4% in East Berlin.<ref>{{Cite web|author= |title=Veränderung der Zweitstimmenanteile der FDP in den Ländern bei der Bundestagswahl 2002 im Vergleich zu 1998|url=https://www.fdp-bw.de/docs/btw02_ver_zw_bund.JPG|work= |publisher=FDP/DVP Baden-Württemberg|accessdate=2017-11-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author= |title=Bundestagswahlen – Berlin-Ost|url=https://www.wahlen-in-deutschland.de/buBerlinOst.htm|work= |publisher=wahlen-in-deutschland.de|accessdate=2017-11-09}}</ref> At the [[Saxony-Anhalt state election, 2002]] failed, the right-wing populist<ref>{{Cite book |first=Tobias |last=Dürr |title=On "Westalgia": Why West German Mentalities and Habits Persist in the Berlin Republic |work=The Spirit of the Berlin Republic |publisher=Berghahn Books |year=2003 |page=47}}</ref><ref name="Soe117">{{Cite book |first=Christian |last=Søe |title=A False Dawn for Germany's Liberals: The Rise and Fall of ''Project 18'' |work=Precarious Victory |year=2005 |page=117}}</ref> [[Party for a Rule of Law Offensive|Schill party]] just short of the 5% threshold (4.5%) and the FDP moved into the state parliament. In [[Berlin state election, 2001|East-Berlin election, 2001]] won the FDP 5.3% (+4.2%) and in [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern state election, 2002|Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]] just short of the 5% threshold (4.7%)
The [[National Democratic Party of Germany]] (NPD) won 9.2% of the vote in [[Saxony state election, 2004|2004 state parliament elections in Saxony]], and the party has eight seats in the state parliament in [[Dresden]], just behind the 13 held by the Social Democrats. In [[Brandenburg state election, 2004|2004]] won the DVU votes in Brandenburg (+0.8%). In [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]] was the NPD represented since [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern state election, 2006|2006]].<ref>{{Cite web|author= |title=Right-Wing Extremists Find Ballot-Box Success in Saxony |url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/germany/0,1518,558508,00.html |work= |publisher=Spiegel International |date=2008-09-06 |accessdate=2009-10-11}}</ref>
In the [[Saxony state election, 2009|Saxony state election]] of September 2009 the NPD lost votes (-3.6%) and seats (-4),<ref>{{Cite web|author=|title=Landtagswahl in Sachsen|url=http://www.mdr.de/sachsen/wahlen/landtagswahl/|work=|publisher=[[Mitteldeutscher Rundfunk]]|date=|accessdate=2009-10-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091012230131/http://www.mdr.de/sachsen/wahlen/landtagswahl/|archivedate=2009-10-12|df=}}</ref> while [[Brandenburg state election, 2009|in the same month]] the [[German People's Union]] lost its representation in the [[Landtag of Brandenburg]].<ref>{{Cite web|author=|title=Landtagswahl Brandenburg 2009|url=http://wahlarchiv.tagesschau.de/wahlen/2009-09-27-LT-DE-BB/index.shtml|work=|publisher=[[Tagesschau (Germany)|Tagesschau]]|date=|accessdate=2009-10-22|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090930054005/http://wahlarchiv.tagesschau.de/wahlen/2009-09-27-LT-DE-BB/index.shtml|archivedate=2009-09-30|df=}}</ref>
A survey of 14- to 25-year-olds carried out by the Forsa opinion poll institute in 2007 found that one out of two youths in eastern Germany now believe that National Socialism had "its good sides".<ref name="tol">{{cite news |author= |title=Neo-Nazi rampage triggers alarm in Berlin |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article2295519.ece |work= |publisher=The Times |date=2007-08-20 |accessdate=2009-10-11 | location=London | first=Roger | last=Boyes}}</ref>
In 2009, [[Junge Landsmannschaft Ostdeutschland]], which is supported by the NPD, organized a march on the anniversary of the [[Bombing of Dresden in World War II]]. There were 6,000 Nationalists, met by tens of thousands of ″anti-Nazis″ and several thousand police.<ref>{{Cite web| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=aGstsMp983DI&refer=worldwide| title=Skinheads, Neo-Nazis Draw Fury at Dresden 1945 ‘Mourning March’ |accessdate=2009-02-14|author=Patrick Donahue}}</ref>
The Free Voters of Germany emerged in 2009 from the Land Brandenburg regional branch of [[Free Voters]], after this had been excluded because of "signs of right infiltration" from the Federal Association of Free Voters Germany.<ref name="pri.1163726">[http://www.pr-inside.com/de/freie-waehler-schliessen-zwei-landesverbaende-wege-r1163726.htm ''Freie Wähler schließen zwei Landesverbände wegen Rechtskurs aus,''] pr-inside.com ([[Associated Press]]), 4. April 2009.</ref>
In the [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern state election, 2011]], the NPD lost 1.3% and 1 seat, but won in [[Saxony-Anhalt state election, 2011|Saxony-Anhalt]] compared with the DVU 1.6%.
====AfD (2013–present)==== [[File:Btw13 afd zweit endgueltig.svg|thumbnail|right|Second vote share percentage for AfD in the 2013 federal election in Germany, final results]] [[File:Btw17afd.svg|thumb|250px|Second vote share percentage for AfD in the 2017 federal election in Germany, final results]] In the [[German federal election, 2013]], [[Alternative for Germany]] (AfD) had its strongest vote in Eastern Germany, and again in 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/sep/28/is-germanys-election-result-the-revenge-of-the-east|title='Revenge of the East'? How anger in the former GDR helped the AfD|first=Philip|last=Oltermann|date=28 September 2017|publisher=|via=www.theguardian.com}}</ref> The party is seen as having an anti-immigration approach.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/anti-immigrant-afd-party-draws-in-more-germans-as-vote-nears-1505986206|title=Anti-Immigrant AfD Party Draws In More Germans as Vote Nears|first=Anton|last=Troianovski|date=21 September 2017|publisher=|via=www.wsj.com}}</ref>
The [[Pegida]] has its focus in East Germany.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pegida – "Ein überwiegend ostdeutsches Phänomen"|periodical=|publisher=|url=http://www.deutschlandfunk.de/pegida-ein-ueberwiegend-ostdeutsches-phaenomen.694.de.html?dram:article_id=309152|format=|accessdate=2016-10-01|last=|date=|year=|month=|day=|language=German|pages=|quote=}}</ref> According to a survey by TNS Emnid, in mid-December 2014, 53% of East Germans in each case understood the PEGIDA demonstrators. (48% in the West)<ref>[http://www.n24.de/n24/Nachrichten/Politik/d/5860796/mehrheit-der-ostdeutschen-zeigt-verstaendnis.html ''Mehrheit der Ostdeutschen zeigt Verständnis.''] In: ''[[N24 (Germany)|N24]]'', 14. Dezember 2014.</ref>
In 2014, the NPD in [[Saxony state election, 2014|Saxony]] cut short on the threshold (4.9%), but AfD entered the state parliaments in Saxony, [[Brandenburg state election, 2014|Brandenburg]] and [[Thuringian state election, 2014|Thuringia]].
In 2016, AfD reached at least 17% in [[Saxony-Anhalt state election, 2016|Saxony-Anhalt]],<ref>Statistisches Landesamt Sachsen-Anhalt: [http://www.stala.sachsen-anhalt.de/wahlen/lt16/erg/kreis/lt.15.ergtab.frametab.html Wahl des 7. Landtages von Sachsen-Anhalt am 13. März 2016, Sachsen-Anhalt insgesamt]</ref> [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern state election, 2016|Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]] (where the NPD lost all seats)<ref name="Ergebnis">{{cite web|title=Wahl zum Landtag in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern 2016|trans-title=|periodical=|publisher=Statistisches Amt MV: Die Landeswahlleiterin|url=http://service.mvnet.de/wahlen/2016_land/dateien/atlanten/ergebnisse.2016/landtagswahl.html|accessdate=2016-09-14|last=|date=2016-09-04|year=|month=|day=|language=German|pages=|quote=}}</ref> and [[Berlin state election, 2016|East Berlin]];<ref name="Berlin">{{cite web|url=https://wahl.tagesschau.de/wahlen/2016-09-18-LT-DE-BE/index.shtml|title=tagesschau.de|first=|last=tagesschau.de|website=wahl.tagesschau.de}}</ref> whereas they won up to 15% in [[Baden-Württemberg state election, 2016|Baden-Württemberg]],<ref name="StatLandBW">Statistisches Landesamt Baden-Württemberg: [http://www.statistik-bw.de/Wahlen/Landtag/02035000.tab?R=LA Endgültiges Ergebnis der Landtagswahl am 13. März 2016, Land Baden-Württemberg]</ref> [[Rhineland-Palatinate state election, 2016|Rhineland-Palatinate]]<ref>[http://www.wahlen.rlp.de/de/ltw/wahlen/2016/land/ Landesergebnis Rheinland-Pfalz - Endgültiges Ergebnis] Der Landeswahlleiter Rheinland-Pfalz</ref> and West Berlin.<ref name="Berlin"/>{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}}
In 2015, Rhineland-Palatinate interior minister Roger Lewentz said the former communist states were ″more susceptible″ to ″xenophobic radicalization″ because Eastern Germany had not had the same exposure to foreign people and cultures over a period of decades that the people in the west of the country have had.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/eastern-germany-more-susceptible-to-xenophobic-radicalization/a-18683054|title=Eastern Germany 'more susceptible' to 'xenophobic radicalization' - News - DW - 31.08.2015|first=Deutsche Welle|last=(www.dw.com)|website=DW.COM}}</ref>
In the [[German federal election, 2017|2017 Federal Election]], AfD reached ~ 22%<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wahlen-in-deutschland.de/buBundOst.htm|title=Neue Bundesländer und Berlin-Ost Zweitstimmen-Ergebnisse|last=|first=|date=|website=www.wahlen-in-deutschland.de|access-date=}}</ref> in the East and ~ 11%<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wahlen-in-deutschland.de/buBundWest.htm|title=Alte Bundesländer und Berlin-West Zweitstimmen-Ergebnisse|last=|first=|date=|website=www.wahlen-in-deutschland.de|access-date=}}</ref> in the West.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://wahl.tagesschau.de/wahlen/2017-09-24-BT-DE/index-content.shtml| title=Bundestagswahl 2017}}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=October 2017}} The AfD became even the strongest party in Saxony.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.welt.de/politik/deutschland/article168995513/AfD-ist-in-Sachsen-jetzt-die-staerkste-Kraft.html| title=AfD ist in Sachsen jetzt die stärkste Kraft}}</ref>
