[[File:Bob's Mob cropped.jpg|thumb|Protest sign about Marryatt's 2011 pay rise]] '''Tony Marryatt''' (born 1954) is a senior manager employed by local government in New Zealand. Between 2007 and 2013, he was the [[chief executive officer]] (CEO) of [[Christchurch City Council]], succeeding Lesley McTurk. He lost his position over the city council being stripped of its building consent accreditation.
==Professional career== Marryatt served as the [[CEO]] of [[Hamilton, New Zealand|Hamilton City Council, New Zealand]] from 1996 to 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hamilton.co.nz/news/pageid/2145834348 |title=Hamilton City Council - CEO resigns to take up job in Christchurch |date=15 Feb 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100525003331/http://hamilton.co.nz/news/pageid/2145834348 |archivedate=May 25, 2010 }}</ref>
Marryatt's predecessor at Christchurch City Council, Dr Lesley McTurk, resigned in January 2007 to take up the CEO-role at [[Housing New Zealand Corporation|Housing New Zealand]]. Marryatt's appointment as CEO in Christchurch was announced by mayor Garry Moore on 15 February 2007.<ref name="CCC 2007 appointment">{{cite news |title=Christchurch Council Chief Executive appointed |url= http://www.scoop.co.nz/stories/AK0702/S00160.htm |accessdate=7 January 2012 |newspaper=Press Release: Christchurch City Council (via Scoop)|date=15 February 2007}}</ref>
==Controversy== Maryatt's local government tenure has not been without controversy. He has been held responsible for the loss-making [[Hamilton 400|Hamilton V8 Supercars]] event by his opponents,<ref>{{cite news |url= http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/ceo-defends-part-in-v8-fiasco-4490034 |title=CEO defends part in V8 fiasco |newspaper=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]] |date=31 October 2011 |accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> notably then-mayor of Hamilton [[David Braithwaite]], who frequently clashed with Marryatt.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/waikato-times/news/769274/Citys-CEO-went-too-far |newspaper=[[Waikato Times]] |date=19 December 2008 |title=City's CEO 'went too far' |accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> In late 2011 he, along with the [[Bob Parker (mayor)|Bob Parker]]-led Christchurch City Council, garnered controversy for accepting a $70,000 pay rise as the council's CEO.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://tvnz.co.nz/national-news/christchurch-protest-over-city-chief-s-pay-rise-4666796 |newspaper=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]] |date=22 December 2011 |title=Christchurch protest over city chief's pay rise |accessdate=21 October 2013}}</ref> This culminated in a protest rally attended by some 4,000 people in February 2012. In late August of that year, it emerged that Marryatt had taken a personal grievance against city councillors. Whilst the case was settled before it went to court, the city council reimbursed his legal costs, which were between NZ$10,000 to NZ$30,000.<ref>{{cite news|last=Mathewson |first=Nicole |title=Marryatt's legal action criticised |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/7597953/Marryatts-legal-action-criticised |accessdate=23 September 2012|newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=3 September 2012|page=A1}}</ref> Maryatt was also condemned by the Canterbury Employers Chamber of Commerce for his decision to grant council staff an extra 11 days leave a year without first seeking approval from elected city councillors.<ref>{{cite news |last1= Cairns |first1 =Lois |title=Council leave inquiry sought |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/7945347/Council-leave-inquiry-sought |accessdate=21 October 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=14 November 2012}}</ref>
With effect from 8 July 2013, Christchurch City Council has been stripped of its accreditation for issuing building consents. This comes in the middle of a rebuild period following the devastating February [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]].<ref name="CCC stripped">{{cite news |last1= Cairns |first1 =Lois |last2 =Young |first2 =Rachel |title=Council to be banned from issuing consents |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/8862238/Council-to-be-banned-from-issuing-consents |accessdate=1 July 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=1 July 2013}}</ref> City councillors found out earlier in June through the media that [[International Accreditation New Zealand]] (IANZ) had written to council and threatened to withdraw accreditation, with Marryatt replying that Parker and other councillors were kept in the dark because he was confident staff were addressing issues raised by IANZ, and that the June 28 deadline would be met."<ref>{{cite news |last1 =Cairns |first1 =Lois |last2 =Young |first2 =Rachel |title=Marryatt regrets letter surprise |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/8799213/Marryatt-regrets-letter-surprise |accessdate=1 July 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=15 June 2013}}</ref> A [[The Crown|Crown]] manager, Doug Martin, has been installed to reform the council's consenting department.<ref>{{cite news |last2 =Conway |first2 =Glenn |last1 =Young |first1 =Rachel |title='Major challenges' ahead <!-- Online version has different title: "Council consents backlog is growing" --> |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/9127157/Council-consents-backlog-is-growing |accessdate=21 October 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=5 September 2013 |page=A2}}</ref> Marryatt lost his job over the affair, but stayed on the payroll until November 2013 and received a total of $500,000 on departure.<ref>{{cite news |last =Conway |first =Glenn |title=Controversial Marryatt to leave Christchurch council |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/national/politics/local-body-elections/9161306/Controversial-Marryatt-to-leave-Christchurch-council |accessdate=21 October 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=13 September 2013 |page=}}</ref> Parker, who had backed the controversial CEO over the years, took his part of the responsibility and decided not to stand for re-election for a [[Christchurch mayoral election, 2013|third term as mayor]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Conway |first=Glenn |title='This happened on my watch' - Parker |url= http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/local-elections-2013/8887205/This-happened-on-my-watch-Parker |accessdate=6 July 2013 |newspaper=[[The Press]] |date=6 July 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}<!-- *[http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/5591871/Council-cuts-Marryatts-term-by-half Council cuts Marryatt's term by half] *[http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/5627660/Councillor-quits-felt-almost-irrelevant Councillor quits, felt 'almost irrelevant'] *[http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/christchurch-earthquake-2011/6197059/Councils-year-marred-by-infighting Council's year marred by infighting] *[http://www.stuff.co.nz/waikato-times/news/4459611/V8s-Whos-to-blame V8s: Who's to blame?] *[http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/lifestyle/4046627/A-day-with-Bob A day with Bob] -->
{{Christchurch earthquakes}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Marryatt, Tony}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People associated with the 2011 Christchurch earthquake]] [[Category:1966 births]] [[Category:People from Hamilton, New Zealand]]

{{about|the Buddhist observance|the ordination hall in Thai temples|Ubosot}} {{Buddhism}} The '''Uposatha''' ({{lang-sa|Upavasatha}}) is a [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] day of observance, in existence from the Buddha's time (600 BCE), and still being kept today in Buddhist countries.<ref>For a description of the contemporary practice of the Uposatha in Thailand, see Khantipalo (1982a), which is also excerpted in this article below. Kariyawasam (1995), ch. 3, also underlines the continuity of the ancient ''uposatha'' practice in Sri Lanka: "The ''poya'' [Sinhala for ''uposatha''] observance, which is as old as Buddhism itself, has been followed by the Sinhala Buddhists up to the present day, even after the Christian calendar came to be used for secular matters. Owing to its significance in the religious life of the local Buddhists, all the full-moon days have been declared public holidays by the government."</ref><ref>The uposatha day is sometimes likened to the Judeo-Christian notion of the Sabbath. Pali English dictionaries that define "Uposatha" as "Sabbath," are Buddhadatta (2002), p. 63, and PED(Rhys-Davids & Stede,1921-25), p. 151. For an example of the Uposatha being equated with Sabbath by a modern Buddhist master, see Mahasi (''undated''), p. 2, where he writes: "For lay people, these rules [of discipline] comprise the [[The Eight Precepts|eight precepts]] which Buddhist devotees observe on the Sabbath days (uposatha) and during periods of meditation." Harvey (1990), p. 192, also refers to the ''uposatha'' as "sabbath-like."</ref> The Buddha taught that the Uposatha day is for "the cleansing of the defiled mind," resulting in inner calm and joy.<ref>Thanissaro (1997b); Anguttara Nikaya 3.70: Muluposatha Sutta.</ref> On this day, both lay and ordained members of the sangha intensify their practice, deepen their knowledge and express communal commitment through millennia-old acts of lay-monastic reciprocity. On these days, the lay followers make a conscious effort to keep the [[Five Precepts]] or (as the tradition suggests) the [[Five Precepts#Eight Precepts|Eight Precepts]]. It is a day for practicing the Buddha's teachings and meditation.
==Observance days==
Depending on the culture and time period, uposatha days have been observed from two to six days each lunar month.
===Theravada countries===
In general, Uposatha is observed about once a week in [[Theravada]] countries<ref>, with the full moon being the most important one, followed by the new moon. Each lunar month has eight days after both the new moon and full moon Uposatha days and then either six or seven days after the other two quarter moon Uposatha days. Thus, in relation to the [[Gregorian calendar]]'s seven-day week, sometimes there are two uposatha days in a week (such as occurred the week of August 17, 2006, when uposatha days fell on August 17 and August 23, 2006) and sometimes there are none (such as occurred the week of January 15, 2006, which fell between uposatha days on January 14 and January 22, 2006). Nonetheless, there are four uposatha days a month and the average solar month's week has one uposatha day.</ref> in accordance with the four [[lunar phase]]s: the [[new moon]], the [[full moon]], and the two quarter moons in between.<ref>More specifically, using a [[Buddhist calendar]], Uposatha is observed on the following four days of the lunar month (PTS, 1921-25, pp. 151-2): *first (new moon) *eighth (first quarter or waxing moon) *fifteenth (full moon) *twenty-third (last quarter or waning moon) According to the ''Pali English Dictionary'' (Rhys Davids and Stede, 1921-25, pp. 16, 152), the lunar month's eighth day (that is, the eighth day after the new moon) and twenty-third day (which is the eighth day after the full moon) are called in Pali ''atthama,'' which literally means the "eighth," that is, the eighth day of the lunar half-month.</ref> In some communities, such as in Sri Lanka, only the new moon and full moon are observed as uposatha days.<ref>Nyanaponika & Bodhi (1999), pp. 24, 307 ''n''. 26. Nyanaponika & Bodhi refers to the quarter-moon days as "semi-Uposatha." Harvey (1990), p. 192, states that the ''uposatha'' is observed "at the full-moon, new-moon and, less importantly, two half-moon days." He goes on to state: "Except at times of major festivals, observance [''uposatha''] days are attended only by the more devout, who spend a day and night at their local monastery." [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/kariyawasam/wheel402.html#ch3 Kariyawasam (1995), ch. 3], makes a similar observation in regards to modern Sinhalese society: "The popular practice is to observe [the Eight Precepts] on full-moon days, and, among a few devout lay Buddhists, on the other phases of the moon as well."</ref>
In [[Buddhism in Myanmar|Burmese Buddhism]], Uposatha (called {{my|ဥပုသ်နေ့}} ''ubot nei'') is observed by more pious Buddhists on the following days: waxing moon ({{my|လဆန်း}} ''la hsan''), full moon ({{my|လပြည့်နေ့}} ''la pyei nei''), waning moon ({{my|လဆုတ်}} ''la hsote''), and new moon ({{my|လကွယ်နေ့}} ''la kwe nei'').<ref name="spiro">{{cite book |title=Buddhism and Society: A Great Tradition and its Burmese Viscittudes |last=Melford |first=Spiro |year=1970 |publisher=Harper and Row |isbn= |pages=214–228 }}</ref> The most common days of observance are the full moon and the new moon. In precolonial Burma, Uposatha was a legal holiday that was observed primarily in urban areas, where secular activities like business transactions came to a halt.<ref name="spiro"/> However, since colonial rule, Sunday has replaced Uposatha as the legal day of rest. All major Burmese Buddhist holidays occur on Uposathas, namely [[Thingyan]], the beginning of [[Vassa]] (beginning in the full moon of Waso, around July, to the full moon of Thadingyut, around October). During this period, Uposatha is more commonly observed by Buddhists than during the rest of the year. During Uposatha days, Buddhist monks at each monastery assemble and recite the [[prātimokṣa|patimokkha]], a concise compilation of the [[Vinaya]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Buddhism: An Illustrated Review|publisher=Hanthawaddy Printing Works|location=Rangoon, Burma|date=1905|volume=2}}</ref>
===Mahayana countries===
In [[Mahayana]] countries that use the [[Chinese calendar]], the Uposatha days are observed ten times a month, on the 1st, 8th, 14th, 15th, 18th, 23rd, 24th and final three days of each lunar month. Alternatively, one can only observe Uposatha days six times a month; on the 8th, 14th, 15th, 23rd and final two days of each lunar month.<ref>http://ftp.budaedu.org/ebooks/pdf/CE002.pdf</ref> In Japan, these six days are known as the {{nihongo|'''roku sainichi'''|六斎日|Six Days of Fasting}}.
=== Names of Full Moon Uposatha Days === The Pali names of the uposatha days are based on the Sanskrit names of the ''[[Nakshatra|nakśatra]]'' (Pali: ''nakkhatta''), the constellations or lunar mansions through which the moon passes within a lunar month.<ref>See [[Nakshatra]], [[Hindu calendar]], ''Sanskrit English Dictionary'' by Monier Williams, s.v. 'nakśatra'.</ref> {| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto;" |+'''Full Moon Uposatha Day Names''' |- ! Associated Month ! Pali ! Sanskrit ! Burmese ! Khmer ! Sinhala ! Thai ! Days |- | January | Phussa | [[Pushya|Puṣya]] | Pyatho (ပြာသို) | Buss (បុស្ស) | Duruthu | Pusaya (ปุศยะ) | 30 |- | February | Māgha | [[Māgha]] | Tabodwe (တပို့တွဲ) | Meak (មាឃ) | Navam | Makha (มาฆะ) | 29 |- | March | Phagguṇa | [[Pūrva Phalgunī|Phalguṇa]] | Tabaung (တပေါင်း) | Phalkun (ផល្គុន) | Medin (Maedhin) | Pholkuni (ผลคุณี) | 30 |- | April | Citta | [[Nakshatra|Chitrā]] | Tagu (တန်ခူး) | Chaet (ចេត្រ) | Bak | Chittra (จิตรา) | 29 |- | May | Visākhā | [[Viśākhā]] | Kason (ကဆုန်) | Pisak (ពិសាខ) | [[Vesak]] | Visakha (วิสาขา) | 30 |- | June | Jeṭṭhā | [[Jyeshtha|Jyeṣṭha]] | Nayon (နယုန်) | Ches (ជេស្ឋ) | Poson | Chetta (เชษฐา) | 29/30 |- | July | Āsāḷhā | [[Pūrva Ashādhā|Aṣāḍhā]] | Waso (ဝါဆို) | Asath (អាសាឍ) | Esala (Aesala) | Asarnha (อาสาฬหะ) | 30 |- | August | Sāvana | [[Śrāvaṇa]] | Wagaung (ဝါခေါင်) | Srap (ស្រាពណ៍) | Nikini | Savana (สาวนะ) | 29 |- | September | Poṭṭhapāda | [[Pūrva Bhādrapadā|Proṣṭhapāda/Bhādrapadā]] | Tawthalin (တော်သလင်း) | Phuttrobot (ភទ្របទ) | Binara | Phattarapratha (ภัทรปทา) | 30 |- | October | Assayuja | [[Ashvinī|Aśvayuja/Aśvinī]] | Thadingyut (သီတင်းကျွတ်) | Assoch (អស្សុជ) | Vap | Assavani (อัศวนี) | 29 |- | November | Kattikā | [[Kṛttikā|Kāṛttikā]] | Tazaungmon (တန်ဆောင်မုန်း) | Katdeuk (កត្តិក) | Il | Krittika (กฤติกา) | 30 |- | December | Māgasira | [[Mrigashīrsha|Māṛgaśiras]] | Natdaw (နတ်တော်) | Meukesae (មិគសិរ) | Unduvap | Maruekasira (มฤคศิระ) | 29 |}
== History == The word "uposatha" is derived from the [[Sanskrit]] word "upavasatha," which refers to the pre-Buddhistic fast day that preceded sacrifices in the [[historical Vedic religion]].<ref>Khantipalo (1982a); Ñanavara (1993), question No. 1 [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/nanavara/uposatha.html#qa]; and the Pali English Dictionary(Rhys-Davids & Stede,1921-25, p. 151).</ref><ref>Khantipalo (1982a) also translates "uposatha" as literally meaning "entering [a monastery] to stay" but no other source supports this.</ref>{{sfn|Dutt|1988|p=73}}
In the Buddha's time, some ascetics used the new and full moon as opportunities to present their teachings. The Uposatha Day was instituted by the [[Gautama Buddha|Buddha]] at the request of King [[Bimbisara]], and the Buddha instructed the monks to give teachings to the laypeople on this day, and told the monks to recite the [[Patimokkha]] every second Uposatha day.<ref>Rhys Davids & Oldenberg (1881), pp. 240-41. Also see Khantipalo (1982a) and Pali English Dictionary(Rhys Davids & Stede, 1921-25, p. 152).</ref>
== Practice ==
=== Lay practice ===
On each uposatha day, devout [[Upāsaka and Upāsikā]] practice the [[Five Precepts#Eight Precepts|Eight Precepts]],<ref>See, for instance, Kariyawasam (1995), Khantipalo (1982b), Ñanavara & Kantasilo (1993) and Thanissaro (1997b).</ref> perhaps echoing the Buddha's teaching that laypeople should "imitate" [[arhat]]s on Uposatha days.<ref>"The Uposatha Observance Discourse" in Nyanaponika & Bodhi, 1999, pp. 216-18 or, using comparable wording, in Nanavara & Khantasilo, 1993</ref>{{quote|The Eight Precepts are modelled after the [[Five Precepts#Ten Precepts|Ten Precepts]] observed by [[śrāmaṇera|novice monks]], except that the seventh and eighth precepts for the novices are combined, the ninth novice precept becomes the eighth, and the tenth novice precept (non-acceptance of gold and silver, use of money) is excluded as being impracticable for a lay person.<ref>Nyanaponika & Bodhi (1999), p. 307, ''n''. 26</ref>}}
For lay practitioners who live near a [[vihara]], Uposatha is an opportunity for them to visit it, make [[Offering (Buddhism)|offerings]], listen to dhamma talks by monks and participate in [[Buddhist meditation|meditation]] sessions.
For lay practitioners unable to participate in the events of a local monastery, the uposatha is a time to intensify one's own meditation and Dhamma practice,<ref>Bullitt (2005); and, Khantipalo (1982a).</ref> for instance, meditating an extra session or for a longer time,<ref name="Khantipalo 1982a">Khantipalo (1982a).</ref> reading or [[Buddhist chant|chanting]] special [[Buddhist texts]],<ref>Khantipalo (1982a), for instance, suggests reading one of the following: *Visakhuposatha Sutta ("Discourse to Visakha on the Uposatha with the Eight Practices," AN 8.43) (Khantipalo, 1982b). *[[Metta Sutta|Karaniya-metta Sutta]] ("Discourse on Loving-kindness," [[Sutta Nipata|Sn]] 1.8) (Piyadassi, 1999a). *[[Mangala Sutta|Maha-mangala Sutta]] ("Discourse on Blessings," Sn 2.4) (Narada, 1985). *[[Ratana Sutta]] ("Jewel Discourse," Sn 2.1) (Piyadassi, 1999b). *[[Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta]] ("Discourse on Setting the Wheel of Dhamma in Motion," [[Samyutta Nikaya|SN]] 56.11) (Thanissaro, 1993).</ref> [[anussati|recollecting]]<ref>See, for instance, the "Muluposatha Sutta" (AN 3.70) (Thanissaro, 1997b) regarding Uposatha-specific recollections and Thanissaro (1999) for the general Buddhist practice of recollections. In the Muluposatha Sutta, the Buddha recommends practicing recollection of the [[Three Jewels]] as well as of one's own virtue (''[[Śīla|sila]]'') and of the wholesome qualities that leads to rebirth as a [[Deva (Buddhism)|deva]]. In this sutta, if one spends the Uposatha engaged in such a recollection, then that Uposatha acquires the name of the recollection, such as Dhamma-Uposatha or virtue-Uposatha.</ref> or [[Dāna|giving]] in some special way.<ref name="Khantipalo 1982a"/>
=== Monastic practice ===
On the new-moon and full-moon uposatha, in monasteries where there are four or more [[bhikkhu]]s,<ref>Rhys Davids & Oldenberg (1881), p. 281.</ref> the local Sangha will recite the [[Patimokkha]]. Before the recitation starts, the monks will confess any violations of the disciplinary rules to another monk or to the [[Sangha (Buddhism)|Sangha]].<ref>See, for instance, Buddhadatta (2002), p. 63, and Bullitt (2005).</ref> Depending on the speed of the Patimokkha chanter (one of the monks), the recitation may take from 30 minutes to over an hour. Depending on the monastery, lay people may or may not be allowed to attend.<ref name="Khantipalo 1982a"/>
=== Communal reciprocity ===
Describing his experience of Uposatha day in Thailand, Khantipalo (1982a) writes: {{quote|Early in the morning lay people give almsfood to the bhikkhus who may be walking on almsround, invited to a layman's house, or the lay people may take the food to the monastery. Usually lay people do not eat before serving their food to the bhikkhus and they may eat only once that day.... Before the meal the laity request the Eight Precepts [from the bhikkhus] ..., which they promise to undertake for a day and night. It is usual for lay people to go to the local monastery and to spend all day and night there.... [In monasteries where] there is more study, [lay people] will hear as many as three or four discourses on Dhamma delivered by senior bhikkhus and they will have books to read and perhaps classes on Abhidhamma to attend.... In a meditation monastery ..., most of their time will be spent mindfully employed – walking and seated meditation with some time given to helping the bhikkhus with their daily duties. So the whole of this day and night (and enthusiastic lay people restrict their sleep) is given over to Dhamma.}}
== Special Uposatha days ==
In Thailand five full-moon Uposatha days are of special significance and are called [[puja (Buddhism)|puja]]:<ref>Bullitt (2005). Bullitt orders these special uposatha days in accordance with the Gregorian calendar, where Magha Uposatha thus starts the calendar year. However, in accordance with Asian lunar calendars, where the new year starts in mid April, Visakha Uposatha is the first special uposatha day of the year. The lunar calendar ordering of these days is maintained in this article for primarily two reasons: Visakha Uposatha is the most important of the uposatha festivals; and, ordering these uposatha days in this manner (i.e., Visakha Uposatha [Buddha Day], Asalha Uposatha [Dhamma Day], Magha Uposatha [Sangha Day]) celebrates the [[Triple Gem]] (Buddha, Dhamma, Sangha) in the order in which it is traditionally enumerated. Also see [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/kariyawasam/wheel402.html#ch3 Kariyawasam, ch. 3, "Poya Days,"] where he identifies the relevance of all twelve full-moon uposatha days in contemporary Sinhala culture.</ref> * '''Visakha Puja or Visakha Uposatha '''<ref>"[[Vaisakha|Vesākha]]" (Pali) is the second month of the Buddhist lunar year, usually occurring in the [[Gregorian calendar]]'s February. In Thailand this day is called 'Visakha Puja.' The word ''puja'' means "veneration" or "offering" and in Thailand is suffixed to all Uposatha days. (Pali month names are from the ''Pali English Dictionary'' (Rhys Davids & Stede,1921-25, p. 531 s.v. "māsa").</ref> or '''[[Vesak]]''' ("Buddha Day"): is the most sacred Buddhist holiday. It is the anniversary of the Buddha's birth, awakening and [[parinirvana|parinibbana]].<ref>For Mahayana Buddhists, the celebration of the [[Buddha's Birthday|Buddha's birthday]] is independent of recognitions of his awakening and parinibbana and is celebrated on the waxing moon of the fourth Chinese lunar month.</ref> * '''[[Asalha Puja]]''' or Asalha Uposatha.<ref>"[[Aashaadha|Āsālha]]" (Pali) is the fourth lunar month, usually around July.</ref> ("Dhamma Day"): :anniversary of the Buddha's delivering his first discourse, which is collected as the ''[[Dhammacakkappavattana Sutta]]''. The three-month-long [[Vassa]] retreat starts the following day. * '''[[Pavarana]]''':<ref>Pavarana Day is in the seventh lunar month of [[Asvina|Assayuja]] (Pali), usually in October.</ref> :the end of the Rains Retreat residence during which time each monk atones before the Sangha for any offense they may have committed.<ref>Rhys Davids & Oldenberg (1881), pp. 329-30.</ref> * '''Anapanasati Day''':<ref>Anapanasati Day is the eighth lunar month of Kattika (Pali), usually in November.</ref> Anniversary of the Buddha's delivering the ''[[Anapanasati Sutta]]''. This event is not connected to an Uposatha (Poya) day in Sri Lanka and perhaps is particular to Thailand.<ref>The Anapanasati Sutta ("Mindfulness of Breathing Discourse," [[Majjhima Nikaya|MN]] 118) (Thanissaro, 2006) opens on Pavarana Day in the town of Savatthi where the Buddha declares to an assembly of monks that he is so happy with the assembly's practice that he would stay in Savatthi another month. After that month passes, the Buddha delivers the core instructions of the Anapanasati Sutta, instructions which have guided lay people and monastics to higher achievement for millennia. Thus, given this canonical chronology, Anapanasati Day is celebrated a lunar month after Pavarana Day.</ref> * '''[[Magha Puja]]''' or Magha Uposatha.<ref>"[[Maagha|Māgha]]" (Pali) is the eleventh lunar month, usually around February.</ref> ("Sangha Day"): Anniversary of the assembling of 1250 monks in the Buddha's presence during which time he delivered the "Ovada-Patimokkha Gatha."<ref>The three-line Ovada-Patimokkha Gatha (Pali: "Patimokkha Exhortation Verse") (translated in [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/dhammayut/chanting.html#ovada Dhammayut Order in the United States of America, 1994)] includes the Buddha's famous dictum: "Not doing any evil, doing what is skillful, purifying one's own mind, this is the Buddha's teaching." This verse is familiar to many Westerners because it is rehashed in the widely popular [[Dhammapada]], chapter XIV, verses 183-85 [http://www.accesstoinsight.org/tipitaka/kn/dhp/dhp.14.than.html#dhp-183 (Thanissaro, 1997a)].</ref>
In Sri Lanka, three full moon Uposatha or [[Poya]] days are of special significance.<ref name="accesstoinsight.org">See http://www.accesstoinsight.org/lib/authors/kariyawasam/wheel402.html#ch3 Kariyawasam, ch. 3, "Poya Days."</ref> * '''[[Vesak|Vesak Poya]]''', which is described above. * '''Poson Poya''' corresponds to the Jeṭṭhā uposatha, which falls in June. It is of special significance in Sri Lanka because the monk [[Mahinda (Buddhist monk)|Mahinda]], [[Asoka]]'s son, officially introduced Buddhism to Sri Lanka on this day in the 3rd century B.C. * '''[[Asalha Puja|Esala Poya]]''' corresponds to ''Āsāḷhā uposatha'', the full moon of July, and is described above. This day has special significance in Sri Lanka because it was the day that 56 nobles, headed by Prince Ariṭṭha, became the first Sri Lankans to be fully ordained as a bhikkhus at Cetiyagiri in [[Mihintale]] by Mahinda and his companions. It therefore marks the founding of the Lankan Bhikkhu Sangha.<ref name="accesstoinsight.org"/>
In Tibet and Bhutan, there are four full moon Uposatha days that are of importance<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.astraltraveler.com/calendars/buddhist.html|title=.:. Buddhist Calendar .:. ASTRAL TRAVELER .:.|first=Danyel|last=Seagan|date=|website=www.astraltraveler.com|accessdate=26 March 2018}}</ref> * '''Chotrul Duchen''' * '''[[Vesak|Saga Dawa Duchen]]''' * '''Chokhor Duchen''' * '''[[Lhabab Duchen]]'''
In China, Japan, Korea and Vietnam there are certain full moon Uposatha days of importance.
* '''[[First Full Moon Festival (disambiguation)|First Full Moon Festival]]''', which is celebrated in Buddhist temples and also acknowledges the end of the Lunar New Year.<ref>{{Cite book |title=Encyclopedia of Contemporary Chinese Culture |last=Davis|first= Edward L. |publisher=[[Taylor & Francis]] |year=2009 |isbn=9780415777162 |pages=68}}</ref> * '''[[Buddha's Birthday]]/[[Vesak]]'''
== See also == *[[Buddhist calendar]] *[[Buddhist devotion]] *''[[Dhammika Sutta]]'' *[[List of Buddhist festivals]] *[[Householder (Buddhism)]] *[[Poya]] (Sri Lankan full-moon holiday) *[[Thai lunar calendar]] *[[Vassa]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Convention | name = UppCon | image = | caption = | status = Inactive | location = Uppsala Konsert & Kongress | country = Sweden | first = 2002 | last = 2012 | organizer = Uppsalakai | attendance = 3500 in 2011 }}
'''UppCon''' was a Swedish [[anime]] and [[manga]] convention held annually in [[Uppsala]]. The event, which was arranged by the nonprofit organization Uppsalakai, was the largest event of its type in the Nordic countries.<ref>[http://www.unt.se/uppsala/nedrakning-infor-uppcon-1362826.aspx Nedräkning infer UppCon] ''[[UNT]]'' 2 Juni 2011, retrieved 22 September 2011 {{sv icon}}</ref>. During the 1990s the name had been used by a now defunct [[gaming convention]].
The first of the conventions was held in 2002, at the vintage cinema Slottsbiografen. Over the years the event had grown and in 2009 it had more than 3,000 attendants.<ref>[http://www.unt.se/kultur/mangafantasterna-invaderar-894061.aspx Mangafantasterna invaderar] ''[[Upsala Nya Tidning]]'' 9 April 2010, retrieved 4 February 2011 {{sv icon}}</ref>
The conventions usually lasted for three days, from Friday to Sunday, where people with similar interests for example met up to watch [[anime]], compete in [[cosplay]]-contests and play videogames.
Many organizations had put up tables to display products they had for sale. Most of them sold imported goods from [[Japan]], such as [[manga]], [[anime]], figures, dolls, clothes and candy such as [[Pocky]].
The eleventh UppCon was held on June 3–5, 2011.<ref>http://www.uppcon.se</ref> In May 2012 it was reported that the UppCon: 12-event would be the last UppCon arranged by its founders.<ref>http://www.unt.se/uppsala/sista-aret-for-uppcon-1758249.aspx</ref>
==History==

Homepage |publisher=uppcon.com |accessdate=2012-01-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120115090509/http://12.uppcon.se/move |archive-date=2012-01-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> and [[Screw (band)]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://12.uppcon.se/screw |title=UppCon: 11 - revision.text:
The '''Vilatte Orders''' are awards or decorations associated [[Joseph René Vilatte]] which include the Order of the Crown of Thorns (OCT) and the Order of the Lion and the Black Cross (OLBC). Both are condemned by the [[Holy See]] and Italy lists both as illegal decorations.{{efn|A 1981 Italian law punishes violators who use honors with a fine of up to L. 2,500,000 (€ 1,291.14); and punishes violators who confer honors with imprisonment from six months to two years and a fine from L. 1,250,000 (€ 645.57) to L. 2,500,000 (€ 1,291.14). {{cite web|location=Rome|publisher=Governo Italiano. Presidenza del Consiglio dei ministri|website=Presidenza del Consiglio dei ministri|author=Governo Italiano. Ufficio del cerimoniale di Stato e per le Onorificenze|authorlink=|title=Uso delle onorificenze|language=Italian|trans-title=|year=|url=http://www.governo.it/Presidenza/onorificenze_araldica/onorificenze/uso.html|accessdate=2013-12-18|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6LxkY9L2w?url=http://www.governo.it/Presidenza/onorificenze_araldica/onorificenze/uso.html|archivedate=2013-12-18|deadurl=no|df=}} Which cites {{cite act|title=|number=689|language=Italian|date=1981-11-24|article=|url=|accessdate=2013-12-18}} Act of the Italian Parliament. }} The [[International Commission on Orders of Chivalry]] (ICOC) includes a list of ''ecclesiastical decorations'' in its Register since 1998, which only "possess full validity as awards of merit or honours within the respective Churches which have instituted them" but excludes bodies "which are often created as a purely private initiative, and which subsequently place themselves under the 'protection' of a Patriarchal See or Archbishopric."{{cite book|location=[s.l.]|publisher=[s.n.]|author=International Commission for Orders of Chivalry|authorlink=International Commission on Orders of Chivalry|title=Register of Orders of Chivalry|year=2006|type=pamphlet|chapter=Ecclesiastical Decorations|url=http://www.icocregister.org/2006ecclesiasticaldecorations.htm|accessdate=2013-06-27|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120190731/http://www.icocregister.org/2006ecclesiasticaldecorations.htm|archivedate=2008-11-20|deadurl=no}} Also {{cite book|location=[s.l.]|publisher=[s.n.]|author=International Commission for Orders of Chivalry|authorlink=International Commission on Orders of Chivalry|title=Register of Orders of Chivalry|year=2007|type=pamphlet|at=xiv, xix–xx|url=http://www.icocregister.org/2007ICOCRegister.pdf|accessdate=2013-06-27}} Neither the {{abbr|OCT|Order of the Crown of Thorns}} or {{abbr|OLBC|Order of the Lion and the Black Cross}} are found in the {{abbr|ICOC|International Commission on Orders of Chivalry}} Register. The {{abbr|ICOC|International Commission on Orders of Chivalry}} suggests to authorities "to use more proper terms for any future creations of awards" and states it should be "clearly understood that the decorations [...] are not considered by the Commission to be [[Chivalric order|Chivalric]] in nature even though several may use the term '[[Order (honour)|Order]]' in their styles and imitate Chivalric titles." ==Order of the Crown of Thorns== The awards associated with Vilatte include those named ''The Chivalrous and Religious Order of the Crown of Thorns'' (OCT) (''{{lang|fr|L'Ordre Souverain, Chevaleresque, Nobilaire et Religieux de la Couronne d'Epines}}''), ''The Sovereign, Knightly and Noble Order of the Lion and the Black Cross'' (OLBC) (''{{lang|fr|L'Ordre Souverain, Chevaleresque, et Noble du Lion et de Croix Noire}}'' (OLCN)). Louis-François Girardot and Vilatte originated a pair of {{abbr|OCT|Order of the Crown of Thorns}} groups. The two separately founded {{abbr|OCT|Order of the Crown of Thorns}} ''orders'' had the same name but different origins and were combined, although it is not clear what that meant. The San Luigi organization says that the orders were inspired by the ''{{lang|fr|Ordre du Genest}}'', founded by King [[Louis IX of France]], and also that "it is not asserted that there is a continuous and historically verifiable link between the present-day Order and these bodies."{{cite web|location=London|publisher=Abbey-Principality of San Luigi|work=Orders|title=Statutes of the Order of the Crown of Thorns|url=http://san-luigi.org/orders/statutes-of-the-order-of-the-crown-of-thorns/|accessdate=2013-03-30|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FWGRqCgK?url=http://san-luigi.org/orders/statutes-of-the-order-of-the-crown-of-thorns/|archivedate=2013-03-31|deadurl=no|df=}}{{cite encyclopedia|location=Paris|publisher=Hachette et cie|encyclopedia=Dictionnaire historique des institutions, moeurs et coutumes de la France|language=French|year=1884|edition=6|volume=1|last=Chéreul|first=Pierre Adolphe|title=Chevalerie (Ordres de)|pages=147|url=https://archive.org/download/dictionnairehist01chre/dictionnairehist01chre.pdf|accessdate=2012-03-21|archiveurl=https://archive.org/details/dictionnairehist01chre|archivedate=2012-03-21|deadurl=no}} Also: {{cite encyclopedia|title=Genest ou Genêt (Ordre du)|page=485}} There are two separate foundation stories for the {{abbr|OCT|Order of the Crown of Thorns}}; one in 1883, the other in 1891. These foundation stories were not believed by some during Vilatte's lifetime; Guénon wrote that "dignitaries of this Church have a mania for titles of nobility as others have for fantastic decorations; thus [... Vilatte] invented the 'Order of the Crown of Thorns'."{{cite book|location=Hillsdale, NY|publisher=Sophia Perennis|last=Guénon|first=René|authorlink=René Guénon|others=translated by Alvin Moore, Jr.|title=Theosophy: History of a Pseudo-Religion|year=2004|origyear=First published 2003|isbn=0-900588-79-9|chapter=The Old Catholic Church|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7_WwVFntyFwC&lpg=PA216}} Translation of {{cite book|location=Paris|publisher=Nouvelle librairie nationale|last=Guénon|first=René|authorlink=René Guénon|title=Le théosophisme: histoire d'une pseudo-religion|year=1921|language=French|oclc=|chapter=L'Église vieille-catholique|url=https://archive.org/download/lethosophismeh00gu/lethosophismeh00gu.pdf|accessdate=2013-06-26|archiveurl=https://archive.org/details/lethosophismeh00gu|archivedate=2010-10-14|deadurl=no}}{{rp|page=216}} The organization acknowledges the lack of verifiable facts about the monastery but says that some documents were destroyed in a house fire in 1918 and other documents were seized by the Vatican in 1929 after Vilatte's death. ===1883 foundation story=== {{distinguish|text=the [[Christian martyrs]] who lived {{Circa|1880}} in Ghadames.{{catholic|inline=1|volume=13|last=Goyau|first=Georges|authorlink=Georges Goyau|wstitle=Vicariate Apostolic of Sahara}}{{efn|The Missionaries of Our Lady of Africa of Algeria, known after their [[religious habit|habit]] as the White Fathers, did found a station in Ghadames, Goyau describes, in the ''Catholic Encyclopedia'', those [[Christian martyrs]] in an article about the former Roman Catholic missionary jurisdiction in [[French Algeria|colonial Algeria]] and Libya known as the [[Apostolic Vicariate of Sahara]]: "In 1881 Father Richard set out from Ghadames, having become so [[Arab people|Arabian]] in speech and bearing that no one suspected his nationality. He intended to establish himself with Fathers Morat and Pouplard at [[Ghat, Libya|Ghat]] in the midst of the desert, but all three were assassinated. The White Fathers then left Ghadames."}} They were Roman Catholic [[Missionaries of Our Lady of Africa of Algeria]] in the [[Apostolic Vicariate of Sahara]]}} The {{abbr|OCT|Order of the Crown of Thorns}} was reputedly founded in 1883. According to the San Luigi organization, after the [[French protectorate of Tunisia]] was established in 1881, France sought to colonize the [[Ottoman Empire]]'s [[Fezzan]] province as part of the [[Scramble for Africa]]. A small group of French and [[Spanish people|Spanish]] [[Benedictine]] monks settled in [[Ghadames]] on {{date|1883-08-25|mdy}}. Ghadames society in the 1800s is described by Ulrich Harmann, in ''{{lang|de|Die Welt des Islams}}'', as a city with "customary law and administration" with "the norms" established and observed "by the assemblies of the various sub-tribes and codified in ittifaqat" and [[sharia]]. {{cite journal|location=Leiden|publisher=Brill|journal=Die Welt des Islams|issn=0043-2539|volume=38|issue=1|date=Mar 1998|last=Harmann|first=Ulrich|title=The dead ostrich: life and trade in Ghadames (Libya) in the nineteenth century|pages=9–94|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9X8MAQAAMAAJ|jstor=1570730}} {{rp|page=59}} Fezzan was not a ''{{lang|la|[[terra nullius]]}}''; [[Richard Brookes]] described, in ''Brookes' General Gazetter Abridged'', 1796 edition, that Fezzan was "a kingdom in Africa". {{cite encyclopedia|location=London|publisher=B. Law, C. Dilly [etc.]|encyclopedia=Brookes' general gazetter abridged: containing a geographical description of the countries, cities, towns, ports, seas, rivers, lakes, mountains, capes, & in the known world; with the longitude, latutude, bearings and distances from remarkable places, and the events by which they have been distinguished|last=Brookes|first=Richard|authorlink=Richard Brookes|title=Fezzan|year=1796|at=unpaged [p.210]|oclc=719444399|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NrUvAAAAYAAJ&pg=PT210}} The organization says that there is no documentation and that, "It is possible that some had been associated with the former [[Ligugé Abbey]], which had been closed in 1880 with most of the members of the community then moving to [[Abbey of Santo Domingo de Silos|Silos Abbey]] in [[Spain]]." It is unclear if the monastery was a satellite of a mother [[abbey]], if it was ever considered stable enough and large enough to be elevated to the rank of an abbey, if they had the canonically required number of twelve monks to elect an [[abbot]], if his election received the approbation of their provincial prior, if after his ecclesiastical confirmation he received abbatial blessing from any bishop in communion with the Holy See, or even if any of their actions were sanctioned at all.{{Catholic|inline=1|volume=12|last=Ott|first=Michael|authorlink=|wstitle=Priory}}{{Catholic|inline=1|volume=12|last=Ott|first=Michael|authorlink=|wstitle=Prior}}{{Catholic|inline=1|volume=1|last=Oestereich|first=Thomas|authorlink=|wstitle=Abbot}} Nevertheless, the monks called their monastery the ''Abbey-Principality of San Luigi'' and they claimed sovereignty, as a [[theocracy]], over the surrounding secular territory. Disease was endemic; attempts to convert the local [[Muslim]] population to Catholicism were rejected; and in less than a year, on {{date|1884-08-02|mdy}}, the monastery was sacked and at least one monk was murdered. Five monks, including what the organization calls their third abbot, José Mendoza, survived and were exiled. Mendoza was somehow elected by less than the canonically required twelve monks. Without mentioning the [[Sahara]] and [[Sahel]] situated between Ghadames and the [[Sudd]], the organization says that the monks traveled across the Sudd and arrived in the Kingdom of [[Bunyoro]]-Kitara on {{date|1885-03-15|mdy}}. There, the organization says, [[Omukama of Bunyoro|Omukama]] [[Kabarega of Bunyoro]] granted territory to the monks to settle and establish a monastery. The organization says that Kabarega conferred a title, Mukungu of the Chieftainship of the Ancient Abbey-Principality of San Luigi, upon Mendoza. In 1888, all the monks, except for Mendoza, died from an epidemic; Mendoza abandoned the monastery in Bunyoro and returned to Europe. The organization says that "legalization by a French government official established the recognition of the Abbey-Principality by the French state"{{elucidate|reason=What does legalization mean in this context? Is it notarizing something? Is it recording something in a logbook? Is it registering a name?|date=May 2013}} when [[Mayor]] Eugène Clairet of [[Seine-Port]] in [[Île-de-France]], was apparently involved in some way with some type of transfer of titles from Mendoza to Girardot.{{cite web|location=London|publisher=Abbey-Principality of San Luigi|work=History|title=Part 1 – Fezzan, Bunyoro and the pre-Vilatte era|url=http://san-luigi.org/history/|accessdate=2013-03-23|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FLMwEMQ6?url=http://san-luigi.org/history/|archivedate=2013-03-23|deadurl=no|df=}} On {{date|1899-05-07|mdy}}, Girardot transferred those Mendoza titles to Vilatte, with Clairet somehow involved again.{{cite web|location=London|publisher=Abbey-Principality of San Luigi|work=History|title=Part 2 – The Vilatte era and beyond|url=http://san-luigi.org/history/history-part-2/|accessdate=2013-03-23|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FLNKjlBz?url=http://san-luigi.org/history/history-part-2/|archivedate=2013-03-23|deadurl=no|df=}} The organization says that the monastery, of at least seven monks, "was constitutionally independent as a theocratic state" and a "colonising power" under which "the local population had no political rights whatsoever" and "were to be subjugated under the absolute rule" of the monastery. The organization confers reputed titles of nobility The organization also describes itself as an Old Catholic church.{{cite web|location=London|publisher=Abbey-Principality of San Luigi|work=Ecclesia|title=The Ecclesial Jurisdiction of San Luigi|url=http://san-luigi.org/ecclesia/the-ecclesial-jurisdiction-of-san-luigi/|accessdate=19 April 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FzzJ2V3w?url=http://san-luigi.org/ecclesia/the-ecclesial-jurisdiction-of-san-luigi/|archivedate=19 April 2013|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} The organization believes itself to be the legitimate ''[[de jure]]'' government-in-exile of its former territory in the Fezzan. "The Abbey-Principality aims ultimately to secure the territorial restoration of the original Abbey-Principality in Libya, but is aware that political and related considerations are likely to preclude this objective for the time being". The organization also believes that it is also theoretically empowered to open embassies although it has not done so as yet. In 1957, Girardot recanted his 1883 foundation story.{{cite book|location=Ottawa|publisher=Christian Catholic Church of Canada|last=Girardot|first=Louis-François|editor-last=Thériault|editor-first=Serge A|others=Translated by the editor|title=Statement by Louis-François Girardot regarding the Abbey-Principality of San Luigi and its Order of the Crown of Thorns, Said of the Lion and Black Cross made on August 14 and 11 October 1957|date=2012-07-22|url=http://www.ccrcc.ca/documents/oct_statement20120722b.pdf|accessdate=2013-04-20|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6G1Q38Z0k?url=http://www.ccrcc.ca/documents/oct_statement20120722b.pdf|archivedate=20 April 2013|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite journal|location=Paris|publisher=|journal=[[L'Intermédiaire des Chercheurs et Curieux]]|language=French|issn=0020-5613|volume=21|issue=|date=Sep 1971|pages= |title= |first= |last= |url=}} ===1891 foundation story=== The {{abbr|OCT|Order of the Crown of Thorns}} was also allegedly founded in 1891 and authorized by [[Moran Mar]] [[Ignatius Peter IV]], [[Syriac Orthodox Patriarch of Antioch]].{{cite web|location=London|publisher=Abbey-Principality of San Luigi|work=History|title=The Abbey-Principality in international law|url=http://san-luigi.org/history/the-abbey-principality-in-international-law/|accessdate=2013-04-18|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6FyMgZ2Xo?url=http://san-luigi.org/history/the-abbey-principality-in-international-law/|archivedate=2013-04-18|deadurl=no|df=}} The {{abbr|ICOC|International Commission on Orders of Chivalry}} asserts that because "none of the Eastern Orthodox Patriarchal Sees possess any type of direct [[Sovereignty]], [...] the decorations instituted by them may not be deemed as equivalent to those bestowed by the [[Roman Pontiff]] not only in his Spiritual Capacity but also in his temporal position as Sovereign of the [[Vatican City State]]." "Protection is an attribute of Sovereignty, which none of these Sees actually posses," according to the {{abbr|ICOC|International Commission on Orders of Chivalry}}. Ignatius Peter IV intended this order, according to Paul Schultz's 1977 pamphlet about the history of the group, to be like the [[Knights of Columbus]]. {{cite book|location=Inglewood, CA|publisher=The St. Louis Foundation|last=Schultz|first=Paul|title=A brief history of the San Luigi orders|year=1977|type=pamphlet|url=http://abbeysanluigi.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/a-brief-history-of-the-san-luigi-orders-schultz-1977.pdf|accessdate=2014-02-26|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NgfDHGkb?url=http://abbeysanluigi.files.wordpress.com/2012/02/a-brief-history-of-the-san-luigi-orders-schultz-1977.pdf|archivedate=2014-02-27|deadurl=no|quote=The intent of the establishment of this order in the New World by the Orthodox Patriarch was much the same as that of the fraternal order of Roman Catholic men known as the Knights of Columbus, which was established in 1882.|df=}} ===In popular culture=== The term "Order of the Crown of Thorns" is also used in [[popular culture]]. It appears in a story about a series of [[LEGO]] construction toy creations posted on LEGO [[Fandom|fan community]] websites.{{cite web|location=|publisher=|work=EuroBricks.com|author=Sirens-of-Titan (pseud. of Alex P)|title=Ambush at the Mausoleum (MOC)|date=2011-06-08|url=http://www.eurobricks.com/forum/index.php?showtopic=56407|accessdate=2013-06-29|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Hk51Ww0E?url=http://www.eurobricks.com/forum/index.php?showtopic=56407|archivedate=2013-06-29|deadurl=no|df=}}
{{cite web|location=Queens, NY|publisher=Sean Kenney Design|work=MOCpages.com|series=The Fantasy Adventures Of Asparuh|author=Sirens-of-Titan (pseud. of Alex P)|title=Ambush at the Mausoleum|date=2011-06-08|url=http://www.mocpages.com/moc.php/273606|accessdate=2013-06-29|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Hk5BZKOA?url=http://www.mocpages.com/moc.php/273606|archivedate=2013-06-29|deadurl=no|df=}}
{{cite web|location=Queens, NY|publisher=Sean Kenney Design|work=MOCpages.com|series=The Fantasy Adventures Of Asparuh|author=Sirens-of-Titan (pseud. of Alex P)|title=The Goblin Menace|date=2011-04-29|url=http://www.mocpages.com/moc.php/266338|accessdate=2013-06-29|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Hk5avaCw?url=http://www.mocpages.com/moc.php/266338|archivedate=2013-06-29|deadurl=no|df=}} It also appears in the [[role-playing game]] ''Chaotic Origin'', which includes among its fantasy organizations ''The Seattle Order of the Crown of Thorns''.{{cite web|location=|publisher=|work=ChaoticOrigin.com|author=Eternal (pseud.)|title=The Crown of Thorns|date=2013-02-12|origyear=first posted 2012-12-27|url=http://chaoticorigin.com/showthread.php?tid=99|accessdate=2013-06-29|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Hk6AzpnL?url=http://chaoticorigin.com/showthread.php?tid=99|archivedate=2013-06-29|deadurl=no|df=}} ==Order of the Lion and the Black Cross== ''The Sovereign, Knightly and Noble Order of the Lion and the Black Cross'' (OLBC) (''{{lang|fr|L'Ordre Souverain, Chevaleresque, et Noble du Lion et de Croix Noire}}'' === Valensi affair === On {{date|1911-04-18|mdy}}, ''{{lang|fr|Le Petit Parisien}}'' reported that the Faubourg-Montmartre Police Commissioner and three magistrates searched Guillaume Valensi's home and office were they seized numerous diplomas and the flag of an order created by Valensi, a [[Demographics of Tunisia|Tunisian]].{{cite news|location=Paris|newspaper=Le Petit Parisien|issn=0999-2707|date=1911-04-18|page=1|title=Le trafic des decorations|trans-title=The trafficking of decorations|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k563945b/f1 |accessdate= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151125110822/http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k563945b/f1 |archivedate=2015-11-25 |deadurl=yes}} One of Valensi's accomplices was Clémenti, the president of the ''{{lang|fr|Ligue Nationale Humanitaire}}'', a [[Corsican people|Corsican]].{{cite news|location=New York|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|date=1911-05-21|title=Bogus decorations still dupe French|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1911/05/21/104825671.pdf|accessdate=2013-10-06}} Documents and blank diplomas of decorations of various orders were seized during a search of Clémenti's home. They included a number of blanks printed in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and other bearing what purported to be, the signatures of Clemenceau, [[Henri Brisson]], [[Victor Henri Rochefort, Marquis de Rochefort-Luçay]], [[Léon Gambetta]], and [[Victor Hugo]].{{Source-attribution|{{cite news|location=Auckland|newspaper=New Zealand Herald|issn=1170-0777|date=1911-06-03|page=2|title=Lawyer hoaxes a town|url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=NZH19110603.2.114.16&e=-------10--1----0--|accessdate=2013-10-05|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6K9QyzMra?url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d|archivedate=2013-10-05|deadurl=no|df=}}}} The evidence was filed in criminal court. Following the search, Valensi's brother, a doctor, requested that the court order a psychological evaluation of the accused. According to ''[[North China Daily News|The North-China Herald and Supreme Court & Consular Gazette]]'', Valensi was not placed on trial with the other five men because of his "breakdown of the mental faculties".{{cite news|location=Shanghai|newspaper=The North-China herald and supreme court & consular gazette|lccn=sn97034383|volume=104|issue=2349|date=1912-08-17|origyear=written 1912-07-26|page=455|title=Clever Paris hoax|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/mdp.39015084570848?urlappend=%3Bseq=489|accessdate=2013-10-07}} This publication was the [[newspaper of record]] for the [[British Supreme Court for China and Japan]] and the British Consulate. The investigation was begun after a client became suspicious of the authenticity of the signatures and reported the whole affair. He revealed in a deposition that he purchased a diploma of the Tunisian order of [[Order of Glory (Tunisia)|Nichan Iftikhar]] for eighty francs from Clémenti. According to the deposition, Valensi sent the client to Clémenti, who provided the diploma. Valensi and Clémenti were arrested on charges of fraud and trafficking illegal decorations. According to ''The New York Times'', the ''{{lang|de|Berliner Lokal-Anzeiger}}'' reported that the trafficking in decorations scandal spread as far as [[Berlin]] were many well known persons were decorated. As it spread, searches were carried out against Valensi and his accomplices which led to several arrests. According to the trial record, Valensi's "part in the play was to pose as chief secretary to the [[Bey of Tunis]], in which capacity he was supposed to be able to bestow the order of the Nichan Iftikar on deserving persons, for a consideration." Valensi deceived many people. ''[[The New Zealand Herald]]'' described how the town of [[Lille]] had been "hoaxed in the most complete and amusing manner" by Valensi and two accomplices, who duped the authorities into thinking that they were Moorish notables. Valensi advertised the visit of [[Qaid|Kaid]] Said Garda to Lille, described as a representative of the [[Sultan of Morocco]]. The Kaid and another "Moorish official" appeared, each wearing a [[burnous]], and with them Valensi, in a red [[fez (hat)|fez]]. They were received at the railway station by the local authorities and a number of Lille adherents of the "Order of the Golden Crescent of Morocco". The affair created great excitement in the town. At Valensi's hotel the [[Flag of Morocco]] was flown from the balcony. Speeches were made at a banquet by the Kaid in broken French and Valensi, and subsequently a number of decorations were distributed. The prefect of police in the town was nominated an officer of the "Golden Cross of Italy". Some well-known politicians were implicated in the scandal. It was revealed during the trial, that while in Lille, "the 'ambassadors' invited a couple of ladies whose language and gestures were so highly Parisian that the effect of the 'Mission' was spoilt. This story made everyone in Court laugh [...]" according to ''The North-China Herald and Supreme Court & Consular Gazette''. Vilatte was also implicated in the Valensi affair by being identified as the Marie Timothée of the Principality of San Luigi, whose signature appeared on diplomas of the Order of the Lion and the Black Cross trafficked by Valensi, who was described as a propagator of honorary and bizarre distinctions.{{cite news|location=Paris|newspaper=La Croix|issn=0242-6412|language=French|date=1911-05-16|page=1|title=La vertu récompensée|trans-title=The virtue rewarded|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k257996p/f1|accessdate=2013-10-04|quote={{lang|fr|Marie-Timothée, Archevêque, Prince-Grand Maître des Ordres de la Couronne d'Epines, du Lion et de la Croix-Noire de l'Ex-Abbaye-Principautè de San-Luigi}}}} Vilatte responded to ''{{lang|fr|Le Catholique Français}}'' article, based on ''{{lang|fr|Le Matin}}''{{'}}s article, about the diploma by stating that the story discredited him by incorrectly identifying him as the signatory. He declared that he had nothing to do with the published diploma, with Valensi, or with the Order of the Lion and the Black Cross and that his authentic {{abbr|OCT|Order of the Crown of Thorns}} had nothing in common with the diploma from the Principality of San Luigi. "I do not bear the title of Marie Timothée, much less that of Prince, Grand Master of the Order of the Lion and the Black Cross", asserted Vilatte. He wrote that he never signed any document as Marie Timothée or Mar Timothée and made clear that he was given the religious name of Mar Timothéus I and not Marie Timothée.{{cite news|location=Paris|newspaper=Le catholique français: organe de l'église catholique gallicane|language=French|oclc=420108020|volume=[volume unknown]|issue=[issue unknown]|year=1911|pages=105–106 |title=[title unknown]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HEpXtD5pKk0C&dq=%22ne+porte+pas+le+titre+de+Marie+Timoth%C3%A9e%22}}{{rp|page=105}} Vilatte was correct on two points. Neither ''{{lang|fr|La Croix}}'' nor ''{{lang|fr|Le Matin}}'' mentioned the name "Vilatte" or "Timothéus"; the diploma, which was printed in both ''{{lang|fr|La Croix}}'' and ''{{lang|fr|Le Matin}}'', also did not mention the name "Vilatte" or "Timothéus".{{cite news|location=Paris|newspaper=Le Matin|issn=1256-0359|date=1911-05-15|page=2|title=Pour célébrer les vertus de l'amie de Valensi|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k569794q/f2.image|accessdate=2013-10-04}} ''{{lang|fr|Le Catholique Français}}'' asked Vilatte about the identity of the Mar Timothée, diploma signatory, but he did not respond.{{rp|page=106}} In 1913 ''{{lang|fr|La Revue critique des idées et des livres}}'' printed an article about the Valensi affair based on [[Maurice Pujo]]'s ''{{lang|fr|Pourquoi l'on a étouffé l'affaire Valensi}}''.{{cite journal|location=Paris|publisher=Nouvelle librairie nationale|journal=La revue critique des idées et des livres|language=French|issn=2017-6775|volume=20|issue=114|date=1913-01-13|pages=80–91|last=P. G.|first=|authorlink=|title=L'affaire Valensi|url=http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k56629603/f84.image|accessdate=2013-10-04}} Based on {{cite book|location=Paris|publisher=Nouvelle librairie nationale|series=Cadres de la démocratie|last=Pujo|first=Maurice|authorlink=Maurice Pujo|title=Pourquoi l'on a étouffé l'affaire Valensi: les cadres de la démocratie|language=French|trans-title=Why was the Valensi affair stifled|year=1912|oclc=464981352}}{{rp|page=80}} Pujo connected the Valensi affair to [[organized crime]] centering on Georges Brassard and E. Deyber. Brassard was a wine merchant, a [[Radical Party (France)|Radical Party]] executive committee delegate affiliated with Freemasonry and director of {{lang|fr|l'Agence spéciale parisienne}}.{{rp|pages=81–82}} Deyber was a dismissed {{lang|fr|Sûreté Générale}} Police Commissioner.{{rp|page=82}} Brassard and Deyber, added Pujo, provided houses for white slave trade and prostitution.{{rp|page=83}} Pujo listed eight societies which mushroomed from Brassard's conglomerate or Republican policy as: *National League for Civic Education (''{{lang|fr|la Ligue nationale d'Education civique}}''),{{rp|page=85}} *National Humanitarian League (''{{lang|fr|la Ligue nationale humanitaire}}''),{{rp|page=85}} *League of the Public Interest (''{{lang|fr|la Ligue de l'Intérêt public}}''),{{rp|page=85}} *Grand Prix Humanitarian of France and the Colonies (''{{lang|fr|le Grand Prix Humanitaire de France et des Colonies}}''),{{rp|pages=85–86}} *Red Crescent of Morocco (''{{lang|fr|le Croissant Rouge du Maroc}}''),{{rp|page=86}} "an order which existed only in the fertile imagination of Valensi". *National Society for the Encouragement of Progress (''{{lang|fr|la Société nationale d'Encouragement au progrès}}''),{{rp|page=86}} *Knights of Saint Sebastian and William (''{{lang|fr|les Chevaliers de Saint-Sébastien et Guillaume}}''),{{rp|page=86}} *[[Free State of Counani]] (''{{lang|fr|l'Etat libre de Counani}}''),{{rp|page=86}} which was exposed as a deception by 1906,{{cite journal|location=London|publisher=|journal=Truth|lccn=10011613|volume=59|issue=1532|date=1906-05-09|title=The Counani mystery|pages=1103–1104|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PHQxAQAAMAAJ&dq=counani&pg=PA1103}} Also {{cite journal|location=London|publisher=|journal=Truth|lccn=10011613|volume=59|issue=1536|date=1906-06-06|title=The Counani imposture|pages=1355–1357|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PHQxAQAAMAAJ&dq=counani&pg=PA1355}} according to seized documents, Valensi was Chancellor to the Consul-General in Paris for the make-believe state. Pujo included an excerpt from a letter written by Collet, secretary of most Brassard companies, to Adolphe Brézet, "president of the Free State of Counani", stated that Brézet would receive, among several blank diplomas sent to him, a blank "officer of San Luigi" diploma.{{rp|page=86}} ==Condemnation by the Catholic Church== The Holy See had stated twice, first in 1953 and again in 1970, that it does not recognize either of the orders. [[Guy Stair Sainty]] wrote that an "increasing number of such bodies" troubled the Holy See which "issued statements condemning such 'Orders'" in 1935, 1953, 1970 and 1976. He noted that the "most complete recent condemnation" was included in ''Orders of Knighthood, Awards and the Holy See'', by Archbishop [[Igino Eugenio Cardinale]].{{cite web|location=|publisher=|work= |last=Sainty|first=Guy Stair|authorlink=Guy Stair Sainty|title=The Self-Styled Orders |year= |url=http://www.chivalricorders.org/orders/self-styled/selfstyl.htm|accessdate=2013-06-27|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000511180613/http://www.chivalricorders.org/orders/self-styled/selfstyl.htm|archivedate=2000-05-11|deadurl=no}} The [[self-styled orders]] are described as "originating from private initiatives and aiming at replacing the legitimate forms of chivalric awards."{{cite book|location=[[Gerrards Cross]], GB|publisher=Van Duren|last=Cardinale|first=Hygenius E|authorlink=Igino Eugenio Cardinale|editor-last=Bander van Duren|editor-first=Peter|editor-link=Peter Bander van Duren|title=Orders of Knighthood, Awards and the Holy See|chapter=Autonomous and self-styled orders of knighthood|year=1985|origyear=1983|edition=3rd|isbn=0-905715-26-8|pages=231–237|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cjYOAQAAMAAJ&q=thorns#search_anchor|accessdate=2013-06-27}}{{rp|page=231}} The statement points out that, they "take their name from Orders which have in fact already existed but are now extinct [...] or [...] which had been planned but were never realized or, [...] which are truly fictitious and have no historical precedent at all." While they "[[self-proclaimed|style themselves]] as autonomous," these "private initiatives" qualify their names, according to the statement, with terms "which belong exclusively to authentic Orders duly approved by the Holy See" but are used by these "private initiatives" to "increase the confusion of those who are not aware of the true history of Orders of Knighthood and of their juridical condition." For example, "these alleged Orders claim for themselves [...] such titles as [...] Chivalric, [...] Sovereign, Nobiliary, Religious, [...]" "Among these private initiatives, which in no way are approved of or recognized by the Holy See, one can find alleged Orders such as" ''Saint John the Baptist'', ''The Crown of Thorns'' and ''Lion of the Black Cross''.{{rp|page=232}} The statement explains that, "to avoid equivocations [...] because of the abuse of pontifical and ecclesiastical documents, [...] and to put an end to the continuation of such abuses, entaling harmful consequences for people in good faith, we [...] declare that the Holy See does not recognize the value of the certificates and insignia conferred to the above-named alleged Orders."{{rp|page=233}} According to the {{abbr|ICOC|International Commission on Orders of Chivalry}}, the "only recognised order with the style of 'Sovereign' existing nowadays" is the [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta]] and "whose international diplomatic 'status' as an independent non-territorial power is recognised officially by the Holy See and by many other Governments." According to [[Robert Gayre]] these "Orders" are "clearly recent creations grafted on to old traditions. Such fantasies are not Orders of chivalry no matter how they may ape chivalric insignia and styles."''The knightly twilight'',Robert Gayre, Lochore Enterprises Valletta 1973, p. 89 ==See also== *[[False titles of nobility]] *[[Scam title]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://san-luigi.org/ Abbey-Principality of San Luigi] *[http://orderofthecrownofthorns.org/ Order Of The Crown Of Thorns] *[http://www.ccrcc.ca/en/episcopal_committee/cccc/oce.html Traditional Order of the Crown of Thorns] [[Category:Self-styled orders]]

revision.comment: [[Nikita Khrushchev]] (Никита Хрущёв) was the [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|First Secretary]] in 1956, but not the [[Premier of the Soviet Union]] (1958-1964).
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{other uses}} [[File:Nikita Khrusjtsjov.jpg|thumb|Nikita Khrushchev (1961)]] '''"We will bury you!"''' ({{lang-ru|«Мы вас похороним!»|translit="My vas pokhoronim!"}}) is a phrase that was used by [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|First Secretary]] [[Nikita Khrushchev]] while addressing Western ambassadors at a reception at the [[Embassy of Poland in Moscow|Polish embassy in Moscow]] on November 18, 1956.<ref>[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,867329,00.html "We Will Bury You!"], ''[[Time Magazine]]'', November 26, 1956</ref><ref>"Khrushchev Tirade Again Irks Envoys", ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 19, 1956, p. 1.</ref><ref name="quote">The quote, cited on [http://www.bartleby.com/63/83/183.html Bartleby.com] and [http://www.quotationspage.com/quotes/Nikita_Khrushchev/ QuotationsPage.com].</ref> The phrase was originally translated into English by Khrushchev's personal interpreter [[Viktor Sukhodrev]].<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.kp.ru/online/news/1737040/| script-title=ru:Умер личный переводчик Хрущева и Брежнева Виктор Суходрев|publisher =''[[Komsomolskaya Pravda]]''| language=Russian|accessdate =May 16, 2014}}</ref>
==History== While addressing [[Western World|Westerners]] at the embassy on November 18, 1956, in the presence of [[Polish United Workers' Party|Polish Communist]] statesman [[Władysław Gomułka]], First Secretary Khrushchev said: "About the [[capitalist state]]s, it doesn't depend on you whether or not we exist. If you don't like us, don't accept our invitations, and don't invite us to come to see you. Whether you like it or not, history is on our side. We will bury you!"<ref name="MS">{{cite web | url =https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1368&dat=19561119&id=HWtQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gBAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6057,4980504&hl=ru |title=Envoys Stalk Again As Nikita Rants|work=[[The Milwaukee Sentinel]]| date=Nov 19, 1956| accessdate =April 17, 2016}}</ref> The speech prompted the envoys from twelve [[NATO]] nations and Israel to leave the room.<ref name="MS"/>
During [[1959 Khrushchev visit to the United States|Khrushchev's visit to the United States]] in 1959, the Los Angeles mayor [[Norris Poulson]] in his address to Khrushchev stated: "We do not agree with your widely quoted phrase 'We shall bury you.' You shall not bury us and we shall not bury you. We are happy with our way of life. We recognize its shortcomings and are always trying to improve it. But if challenged, we shall fight to the death to preserve it".<ref>{{cite web | url =http://www.lawac.org/About-Us/LAWAC-History |title=Founding and history|publisher=[[Los Angeles World Affairs Council]]|accessdate =November 21, 2017}}</ref> Many Americans meanwhile interpreted Khrushchev's quote as a [[nuclear weapons|nuclear threat]].<ref>James Stuart Olson, ''Historical dictionary of the 1950s'', Greenwood Publishing Group, 2000, p. 157</ref>
In another public speech Khrushchev declared: "[...] We must take a shovel and dig a deep grave, and bury [[colonialism]] as deep as we can".<ref>Nikita Sergeevich Khrushchev, Sergeĭ Khrushchev, George Shriver, Stephen Shenfield. ''Memoirs of Nikita Khrushchev: Statesman, 1953–1964'', Penn State Press, 2007, p. 893</ref> In a 1961 speech at the [[Institute of Marxism–Leninism]] in Moscow, Khrushchev said, that "[[peaceful coexistence]]" for the Soviet Union means "intense, economic, political and ideological struggle between the [[proletariat]] and the aggressive forces of [[imperialism]] in the world arena".<ref name="birkby">{{cite web | url =http://www.aulibrary.au.edu/multim1/ABAC_Pub/Galaxy-The-English-Department-Journal/n2-6-2013.pdf|title='We will bury you' How Mistranslation Heightened Cold War Tensions|work=Galaxy|author=Dr. Stuart J. Birkby| accessdate =April 17, 2016}}</ref> Later, on August 24, 1963, Khrushchev remarked in his speech in [[Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]], "I once said, 'We will bury you,' and I got into trouble with it. Of course we will not bury you with a shovel. Your own [[working class]] will bury you,"<ref name="kh-explanation">[http://www.quotationspage.com/quotes/Nikita_Khrushchev/ Nikita Khrushchev] on QuotationsPage.com</ref> a reference to the [[Marxist]] saying, "The proletariat is the undertaker of [[capitalism]]", based on the concluding statement in Chapter 1 of the ''[[Communist Manifesto]]'': "What the [[bourgeoisie]] therefore produces, above all, are its own grave-diggers. Its fall and the victory of the proletariat are equally inevitable". In his memoirs, Khrushchev stated that "enemy propaganda picked up the slogan and blew it all out of proportion".<ref>{{cite book | author=Arnold Beichman| title =The Long Pretense: Soviet Treaty Diplomacy from Lenin to Gorbachev| publisher =Transaction Publishers|page =96| isbn =1412837685}}</ref>
Some authors suggest that an alternative translation is "We shall be present at your funeral" or "We shall outlive you".<ref>Moshe Lewin, [https://books.google.com/books?id=ETQpY-32DysC&pg=PA238&dq=%22we+shall+outlive+you%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=rBmUU5mPIevJsQSz64LADg&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=%22we%20shall%20outlive%20you%22&f=false The Soviet Century]</ref><ref>Bill Swainson, [https://books.google.com/books?id=Af84fBmzmVYC&pg=PA518&dq=%22we+shall+outlive+you%22+bury&hl=en&sa=X&ei=FRqUU9v_DIqlsQSxroBo&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=%22we%20shall%20outlive%20you%22%20bury&f=false The Encarta Book of Quotations]</ref><ref>Robert Legvold, [https://books.google.com/books?id=e8j0uy37Wg8C&pg=PT256&dq=%22We+shall+be+present+at+your+funeral%22+bury&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ihqUU4qzAbLFsAS8qYGYBQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22We%20shall%20be%20present%20at%20your%20funeral%22%20bury&f=false Russian Foreign Policy in the Twenty-first Century and the Shadow of the Past]</ref> Authors have suggested the phrase, in conjunction with Khrushchev's overhead hand clasp gesture meant that Russia would take care of the funeral arrangements for capitalism after its demise.<ref>{{citation|title=The Handbook of Conflict Resolution: Theory and Practice|editors=[[Morton Deutsch]], [[Peter T. Coleman (academic)|Peter T. Coleman]], Eric C. Marcus|chapter=Culture and Conflict|publisher=Wiley|year=2011|isbn=9781118046906|p=630|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rw61VDID7U4C&pg=PA630}}</ref> In an article in ''[[The New York Times]]'' in 2018, translator Mark Polizzotti suggested that the phrase was mistranslated at the time and should properly have been translated as "We will outlast you," which gives an entirely different sense to Khrushchev's statement.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/28/opinion/sunday/why-mistranslation-matters.html "Why Mistranslation Matters; Would history have been different if Khrushchev had used a better interpreter? by Mark Polizzotti, New York Times, July 28, 2018]</ref>
First Secretary Khrushchev was known for his emotional public image. His daughter admitted that "he was known for strong language, interrupting speakers, banging his fists on the table in protest, pounding his feet, even whistling".<ref name="birkby"/> She called such behavior a "manner, which suited his goal... to be different from the hypocrites of the West, with their appropriate words but calculated deeds".<ref name="birkby"/> [[Mikhail Gorbachev]] suggested in his book ''Perestroika and New Thinking for our Country and the World'' that the image used by Khrushchev was inspired by the acute discussions among Soviet [[agrarian scientist]]s in the 1930s, nicknamed "who will bury whom", the bitterness of which must be understood in the [[Politics of the Soviet Union|political context]] of the times.
==In popular culture== * Khrushchev's phrase was used as the title of [[Jan Šejna]]'s book on communist [[Cold War]] strategies and of a [[We Will Bury You (comics)|comic book]]. * The phrase also appears in [[Sting (musician)|Sting]]'s song "[[Russians (song)|Russians]]". * It provided the title to a 1962 documentary ''We'll Bury You'' released by Columbia Pictures. * The quote, paraphrased as "We will bury them!", was used as a taunt in the video game ''[[Command & Conquer: Red Alert 2]]'',<ref>{{cite web | url =https://www.gamefaqs.com/pc/476890-command-and-conquer-red-alert-2-yuris-revenge/faqs/20018|title=Command & Conquer: Red Alert 2 – Yuri's Revenge|publisher=[[GameFAQs]]| accessdate =November 18, 2016}}</ref> in which the Soviet Union wages [[World War III]] against the Western Allies. * This event inspired a card<ref>{{cite web | url=https://twilightstrategy.com/2012/10/10/we-will-bury-you/|title=We Will Bury You}}</ref> in favor of the U.S.S.R. in the Cold War themed boardgame [[Twilight Struggle]]. * In issue #12 of Brian K. Vaughan's "Y: The Last Man," a Russian character shouts the phrase when she believes she's being attacked by enemies. * This is also referenced by a worm in the ''[[SpongeBob SquarePants]]'' episode entitled "Rock-a-Bye Bivalve" * In the 2017 film ''[[The Death of Stalin]]'', Khrushchev shortly after [[Lavrentiy Beria|Beria]]'s execution delivers a similar statement to the later speech by telling his corpse that he'll bury Beria in history.
==See also== * [[Kuzma's mother]] * [[Shoe-banging incident]]
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Wikiquote|Nikita Khrushchev}} {{Cold War|state=collapsed}}
