page.title: Wedding of Crown Prince Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala and Sinaitakala Fakafanua

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} [[File:Saione.jpg|thumb|right|220px|Centennial Church in Nuku'alofa, site of the royal wedding.]] The '''wedding of Crown Prince Tupouto'a 'Ulukalala and Sinaitakala Fakafanua''' was held on 12 July 2012, at the Centennial Church in [[Nukuʻalofa]], Tonga.<ref name=rnzi>{{cite news|first=|last=|title= Tonga Crown Prince weds |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=69502 |work=[[Radio New Zealand International]] |publisher=|date=12 July 2012 |accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> Tongan [[Crown Prince]] [[Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala]] married [[Sinaitakala Fakafanua]], his [[second cousin]] and 26th in line to the throne, during the ceremony.<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news|first=Jonathan|last=Pearlman|title= Tongan crown prince marries second cousin |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/australiaandthepacific/tongafrenchpolynesia/9394358/Tongan-crown-prince-marries-second-cousin.html |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |publisher=|date=12 July 2012 |accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref>
The wedding marked the first marriage of a Tongan Crown Prince in sixty-five years.<ref name=telegraph/> However, the union caused some controversy among Tongans, as the bride and groom are second cousins.<ref name=tvnz>{{cite news|first=|last=|title=Royal wedding causes royal divisions |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/world-news/hundreds-gather-catch-glimpse-tongan-royal-wedding-4966074 |work=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]] |publisher=[[TVNZ]] |date=12 July 2012 |accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:Tupoutoʻa ʻUlukalala and Sinaitakala Fakafanua.jpg|thumb|Ulukalala and Fakafanua at an Asia Pacific event in London in 2012.]] Tupouto'a 'Ulukalala became Crown Prince of [[Tonga]] and first in line in royal succession in March 2012 following the death of King [[George Tupou V]] and the ascension of [[Tupou VI]] to the throne.<ref name=rnzi/> The wedding ceremony marked the end of Tonga's one-hundred-day mourning period marking the death of George Tupou V, who died in March.<ref name=telegraph/> The Crown Prince is the son of Tupou VI and the nephew of the late King George Tupou V.<ref name=tvnz2/>
All royal marriages in Tonga are arranged.<ref name=stuff>{{cite news|first=|last=|title= Tongan Queen Mother absent from wedding |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/south-pacific/7271036/Tongan-Queen-Mother-absent-from-royal-wedding |work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |publisher=|date=12 July 2012 |accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> Under Tongan [[royal protocol]] and tradition, members of the royal family may only marry members of Tongan nobility to maintain the royal [[bloodline]].<ref name=telegraph/><ref name=rnzi2>{{cite news|first=|last=|title= Upcoming Tongan royal wedding of cousins prompts controversy |url=http://www.rnzi.com/pages/news.php?op=read&id=69394 |work=[[Radio New Zealand International]] |publisher=|date=8 July 2012 |accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> The bride, Sinaitakala Fakafanua, is also a member of the royal family and 26th person in the [[line of succession]] to inherit the throne.<ref name=telegraph/>
Queen [[Nanasipau'u Tuku'aho]], the wife of the current king, personally arranged the marriage between Crown Prince Tupouto'a 'Ulukalala and Sinaitakala Fakafanua.<ref name=stuff2>{{cite news|first=Michael|last=Field|title=Holiday for royal grandchildren wedding in Tonga |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/world/south-pacific/7241818/Holiday-for-royal-grandchildren-wedding-in-Tonga |work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |publisher=|date=8 July 2012 |accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> The queen pushed for a July wedding, even though the royal family must continue to wear black until February 2013 to mark George Tupou V's death.<ref name=stuff2/> The queen's arrangement was opposed by her husband, King Tupou VI, who questioned whether it was appropriate for second cousins to marry.<ref name=stuff2/>
The Prince was 27 years old at the time of the 2012 wedding, while the bride was 25 years old.<ref name=telegraph/>
==Ceremony== Earlier in the week, a Ma'utohi ceremony was held to mark the issuance of their marriage license.<ref name=rnzi/> The Ma'utohi was followed by a reception, held at Fakafanua's home.<ref name=rnzi/>
The [[wedding ceremony]] was held at the Centenary Church of the [[Free Wesleyan Church of Tonga]] in [[Nuku'alofa]] on 12 July 2012.<ref name=rnzi/> Tupouto'a 'Ulukalala became the first Crown Prince to marry in sixty-five years. The groom wore grey and black [[morning dress]], while the bride wore a long sleeve, [[lace]] [[wedding gown]] with a [[Wedding veil|veil]] that reached the floor of the church.<ref name=tvnz/>
More than 2,000 guests attended the ceremony, including chiefly families from [[Samoa]] and [[Fiji]].<ref name=rnzi/> Noticeably absent from the ceremony were [[Queen Mother]] [[Halaevalu Mataʻaho ʻAhomeʻe]] and her daughter ([[Tupou VI|king's]] sister), [[Salote Mafile'o Pilolevu Tuita|Princess Pilolevu]], who disapproved of the marriage.<ref name=stuff/>
Members of the international media visiting Tonga to cover the wedding were given detailed instructions on how to behave during the ceremony. Photography was banned in sacred areas, with the government warning that it would confiscate or delete any photos taken in prohibited places.<ref name=stuff2/> Photographers were asked to sit on the ground and "stand up quickly" to take a photo before sitting back down.<ref name=stuff2/> Female journalists could not wear sleeveless dresses or shirts and men were to wear suits and ties.<ref name=stuff2/> Umbrellas, hats, and sunglasses were banned throughout the wedding, while gum, food and drinks were not allowed at the [[Royal Palace, Tonga|Tongan Royal Palace]].<ref name=stuff2/>
==Controversy== The marriage between the Crown Prince and Fakafanua caused much controversy over the practice of marrying closely related cousins.<ref name=telegraph/><ref name=tvnz/> The two of them are [[Cousin#Additional terms|double second cousins]] (that is, Fakafanua's father and mother are each the first cousin of the prince's father).<ref name=telegraph/><ref name=tvnz2>{{cite news|first=|last=|title= Tongan royals to wed as nation struggles with economic crisis |url=http://tvnz.co.nz/world-news/royal-wedding-comes-tonga-struggles-economic-crisis-4963710 |work=[[One News (New Zealand)|One News]] |publisher=[[TVNZ]] |date=10 July 2012 |accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> The wedding between the cousins was openly criticised by members of Tongan political and royal circles.<ref name=tvnz/> A leader of New Zealand's Tongan community noted that there is no word for cousin in the [[Tongan language]]; cousins are considered and called "brother" or "sister", which reinforces the controversy among ordinary [[Tongan people|Tongans]].<ref name=ra/>
According to royal sources, [[King Tupou VI]] opposed the marriage due to their close relations and made his disapproval known to members of the royal family.<ref name=stuff2/><ref name=ra/> (The king's wife, Queen [[Nanasipau'u Tuku'aho|Nanasipau'u]], had arranged the royal wedding.)<ref name=stuff2/> Two prominent members of the Tongan royal family, [[Queen Mother]] [[Halaevalu Mataʻaho ʻAhomeʻe]] and the [[Tupou VI|king's]] sister, [[Salote Mafile'o Pilolevu Tuita|Princess Pilolevu]] refused to attend the ceremony.<ref name=stuff/> Daughter of Princess Pilolevu, Hon. Frederica Tuita, who is ninth in line to the throne, openly condemned the union, calling the royal [[arranged marriage]] "extremely arrogant and only perpetuated the motive behind social climbers."<ref name=telegraph/>
Political figures and members of the Tongan community also weighed in on the controversy. [[Pro-democracy]] leader [['Akilisi Pohiva]] criticised the wedding, telling [[TVNZ]], "They are too close...I do not know about biological effects of two close bloods mixed together, but I think they need new blood from outside."<ref name=telegraph/> A leader of Tongans living in [[New Zealand]], [[Will Ilolahia]], stated that many Tongans opposed the second cousins' marriage, but were unwilling to speak out publicly.<ref name=ra>{{cite news|first=|last=|title= Opposition to Tongan royal cousins marriage |url=http://www.radioaustralia.net.au/international/radio/program/pacific-beat/opposition-to-tongan-royal-cousins-marriage/977288 |work=[[Radio Australia]] |publisher=|date=11 July 2012 |accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref> Speculation also centred on possible [[genetic disorder]]s that may result from a marriage of two close relatives.<ref name=tvnz2/><ref name=ra/>
[[ʻAlipate Tuʻivanuavou Vaea|Lord Vaea]], an uncle of the Crown Prince, defended the marriage saying, "It's a new beginning for the royal household. They are both in their 20s, we are looking at that to preserve that [[constitutional monarchy]] within Tonga."<ref name=stuff/> A New Zealand geneticist noted that there is "only a slight risk" of genetic disorders for the offspring of cousins who marry.<ref name=stuff3>{{cite news|first=Anna|last=Turner|title= 'Only slight risk' in cousins marrying |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/the-press/news/7245220/Only-slight-risk-in-cousins-marrying |work=[[Stuff.co.nz]] |publisher=|date=9 July 2012 |accessdate=2 July 2012}}</ref>
In addition to the controversy over royal genetics, the wedding took place amid economic and political uncertainty.<ref name=tvnz2/> Tonga was projected to have the slowest economic growth in the Pacific Islands region during 2012.<ref name=tvnz2/> The royal family agreed to pay for the costs of the wedding; past weddings had been covered by the Tongan government.<ref name=tvnz2/> The government of Tonga may also face a potential vote of [[no confidence]] in the week following the wedding, adding to the country's political and economic woes.<ref name=tvnz2/>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Wedding of Crown Prince Tupouto'a 'Ulukalala and Sinaitakala Fakafanua}} [[Category:Royal weddings]] [[Category:2012 in Tonga]] [[Category:Tongan royalty]] [[Category:Nukuʻalofa]] [[Category:July 2012 events]] [[Category:Royal weddings in the 21st century]]

{{orphan|date=April 2014}}
[[File:Sekttag 1805.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|First page of the manifesto printed for the "Sekttag" of 1805]] The '''Internationaler Sekttag''', '''Weltsekttag''' or '''Sekttag''' is celebrated on '''9 April''', occasionally also upon other days, mainly amongst German-speaking students and members of [[German Student Corps]] and [[Studentenverbindung]]en in general.
The tradition of the '''Weltsekttag''' was founded in the short interim period separating the wars of the Second and Third Coalition, and was initiated amongst others by the German poet [[Ludwig Achim von Arnim]] as a sign of unity against the tyranny of [[Napoleon Bonaparte]].
== History ==
=== The Sekttag of 1805 === [[File:Ludwig Achim von Arnim.jpg|thumb|Achim von Arnim as a student in the year 1804.]]
German student and poet [[Ludwig Börne|Carl Ludwig Börne]] was the first to propose the celebration of a ''Weltsekttag'' during an academic conference held at [[Gießen]] upon the 4th of March 1805, without favouring a particular date, however. The idea was inspired by attempts in the previous years by French vintners to initiate collective day of marked resistance to the coalition wars and the resulting economic conditions which had had a strongly negative effect upon the wine trade. These attempts were largely unsuccessful. Ludwig Achim von Arnim brought the idea to [[Halle an der Saale]], one of the oldest and most important German universities and a centre of the literary movement of the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] in the late 18th and early 19th century, where it was picked up by academic "Kränzchen" ("little circles") and "Convente" ("conventions") of similar corporations.
While it was the poet [[Ludwig Achim von Arnim]] who carried the original idea to Halle, it were the German poets Ludwig Börne and [[Clemens Brentano]] who were responsible for the foundation of the actual tradition of the fixed ''Sekttag'' during the 1805 conference of Gießen, where the decision was accepted.
The ''Beschluss'' (decision) of Gießen read as follows:
{{Quote|Im Einvernehmen mit den politischen und freiheitlichen Organisationen der Studenten in ihrem Lande veranstalten die der Freiheit liebenden Sektgenießer aller Länder jedes Jahr einen Sekttag, oder mehrere, der in erster Linie der Agitation gegen den französischen Tyrannen dient. […] Der Sekttag muß einen Charakter tragen der alle Menschen und Völker repräsentirt und ist sorgfältig vorzubereiten.<ref>Thomas Wilhelm: ''Die Beschlüsse von Gießen 1805 im Kontext der Koalitionskriege'', S. 62.</ref>}}
{{Quote|''In accordance with the political and free organizations of the [[student]]s in their respective [[States of Germany|countries]] the freedom-loving enjoyers of good wine will celebrate yearly a Sekttag as an open sign of protest and agitation against the [[Napoleon Bonaparte|French tyrant]]. […] The ''Sekttag'' must represent in its character all men and all peoples and must be prepared with the greatest care.''}}
The first Sekttag was subsequently celebrated upon the 9th of April 1805 in [[Germany]], [[Austria]] and [[Switzerland]]. The choice of the date was intended to symbolically represent and underline the happy and open-minded character of the Sekttag.
== Situation today == Today, more than 200 years after the original celebrations, students gather yearly upon the 9th of April (and also occasionally upon other days, varying from university city to university city) either under more organized forms of tradition or in less formal gatherings, to drink sparkling wine and honour the memory of the great poets and students. Academic drawings and paintings from the first half of the 19th century not rarely depicts a drinking student who stands upon a table with a glass in his hand, which is a telling reference to the popularity which the tradition would soon come to enjoy. Achim von Arnims immortal "Sektlied" is still sung around the world by German-speaking celebrants:
: ''Schafft her den Sekt! - Ein brav Student'' : ''Zecht fest bis er verreckt'' : ''Voll bis zum Rand, doch eloquent'' : ''Den Vollrausch er bezweckt!''
: ''So stürmen wir mit Saus und Braus'' : ''In die verlog'ne Welt hinaus'' : ''Und wer da bleibt allein zuhaus'' : ''Den holen wir beim Teufel raus!''
: ''Vivallera! Vivallera!''
== Further reading == <references /> * {{cite book | last = Pfeifer | first = Heinz | year = 1893 | origyear = 1878 | title = Geschichte des Corps Rhenania Gießen | location = Corpsarchiv Rhenania Gießen }} * [[Matthias Asche]]: ''Geheime Eliten'', Vortrag auf den ''Bensheimer Gesprächen'' 2011, gekürzt abgedruckt in [[Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung|FAZ]] vom 3. August 2011, Seite N5 unter dem Titel ''Pflanzschule rechtschaffener und dem Vaterlande brauchbarer Männer'' * [[Erich Bauer (Historiker)|Erich Bauer]], F. A. Pietzsch: ''Zum Göttinger Unitistenorden (1786-1799)''. [[Verein für corpsstudentische Geschichtsforschung|Einst und Jetzt]], Bd. 13 (1968), S. 55-67 * [[Friedrich Christian Laukhard]]: ''Der Mosellaner- oder Amicisten-Orden nach seiner Entstehung, inneren Verfassung und Verbreitung auf den deutschen Universitäten dargestellt'', Halle 1799 * Otto Deneke: ''Alte Göttinger Landsmannschaften,'' Göttingen 1937 * [[Peter Kaupp]]: ''Freimaurerei und Burschenbrauch. Kontinuität von Ordenstraditionen im Korporationsstudententum''. [[Verein für corpsstudentische Geschichtsforschung|Einst und Jetzt]], Bd. 46 (2001), S. 33-68 * [[Rudolf Körner]]: ''Vom Wesen der Studentenorden''. [[Verein für corpsstudentische Geschichtsforschung|Einst und Jetzt]], Bd. 6 (1961), S. 141-149 * Friedrich August Pietzsch: ''Die Unitistenorden in Leipzig und das Stammbuch des stud. C. A. Herzog aus den Jahren 1800-1802''. [[Verein für corpsstudentische Geschichtsforschung|Einst und Jetzt]], Bd. 7 (1962), S. 118-130

revision.text:
{{Infobox Wrestling event |name = World Wrestling Peace Festival |image = World Wrestling Peace Festival poster.jpg |caption= |tagline= Harmony for Peace |theme = |promotion = [[All Japan Women's Pro-Wrestling]]
[[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]]
[[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]]
[[Michinoku Pro Wrestling]]
[[National Wrestling Alliance]]
[[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]]
[[World Championship Wrestling]] |brand = |date = June 1, 1996 |venue = [[Los Angeles Sports Arena]] |city = [[Los Angeles, California]] |attendance = 5,964 |lastevent = |nextevent = |event = Interpromotional Inoki shows |lastevent2 = ''[[Collision in Korea]]'' |nextevent2 = ''Final'' }} The '''World Wrestling Peace Festival''' was a [[professional wrestling]] [[supercard]] produced by [[Japanese people|Japanese]] [[professional wrestler]] [[Antonio Inoki]], which took place on June 1, 1996 at the [[Los Angeles Sports Arena]] in [[Los Angeles, California]]. The event was organized by Inoki to promote [[world peace]] with an interpromotional event involving major promotions from around the world.{{cite web |url=http://www.puroresu.com/history/?decade=1990s#1996 |title=1990s: 1996 |author= |work=History of Puroresu |publisher=Puroresu.com |accessdate=May 17, 2012}} Forty wrestlers from six countries ended up taking part in the event.{{cite news |title=WRESTLING FANS MEET IN NAME OF PEACE |author=Monteagudo, Luis |newspaper=[[Press-Telegram]] |date=June 1, 1996}} Inoki's home promotion [[New Japan Pro-Wrestling]] (NJPW), as well as smaller independent groups, represented Japan, while [[World Championship Wrestling]] (WCW) and the [[National Wrestling Alliance]] (NWA) took part on behalf of the United States. The [[World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF) and [[Extreme Championship Wrestling]] (ECW) were the only major promotions in North America not to participate in the show although this was not unexpected given their tense relationships with WCW during the [[Monday Night Wars]]. Both of Mexico's top promotions [[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]] (AAA) and [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL) participated in the event, which was considered unlikely by many in the industry given their own heated rivalry.Rosenbaum, Dave. "Multi-Promotional Supercard! World Wrestling Peace Festival Unites The World!." ''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]''. Fort Washington, Pennsylvania: London Publishing Company. (November 1996): pg. 26–29. The [[Card (sports)#Main event|main attraction]] on the event [[Card (sports)|card]] was a [[tag team]] match with Antonio Inoki and [[NWA World Heavyweight Championship|NWA World Heavyweight Champion]] [[Dan Severn]] wrestling [[Yoshiaki Fujiwara]] and [[Oleg Taktarov]]. Inoki and Severn won the match when Severn pinned Fujiwara with a [[keylock]]. One of the featured bouts on the [[Card (sports)|undercard]] was a title match between [[WCW World Heavyweight Championship|WCW World Heavyweight Champion]] [[Big Show|The Giant]] and [[Sting (wrestler)|Sting]], which The Giant won.{{cite web |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/Bios/bigshow.html |title=The Big Show |author=Milner, John M. |author2=Richard Kamchen |date=October 6, 2004 |work=SLAM! Wrestling Bios |publisher=[[Canoe.ca|SLAM! Sports]] |accessdate=May 17, 2012}} Other matches included a "NJPW vs. [[Michinoku Pro]]" match between [[Jyushin Thunder Liger]] and [[The Great Sasuke]], a [[Professional wrestling match types#Basic non-elimination matches|triangle match]] between [[AAA Americas Heavyweight Championship|AAA Americas Heavyweight Champion]] [[Konnan]], [[Chris Jericho]] and [[Bam Bam Bigelow]],{{cite web |url=http://slam.canoe.ca/Slam/Wrestling/Bios/konnan.html |title=Konnan |author=Milner, John |author2=John Molinaro |date=October 21, 2005 |work=SLAM! Wrestling Bios |publisher=[[Canoe.ca|SLAM! Sports]] |accessdate=May 17, 2012}} and a tag team match pitting [[Perro Aguayo]] and [[La Parka]] against [[Pierroth Jr.]] and [[Cibernetico]]. The event had an attendance of 5,964, far less than the 17,000 promoters were expecting, which was attributed to a poor choice of venue and lack of advertising. Though not as financially successful as Inoki's ''[[Collision in Korea]]'' show the previous year, he was widely praised for his efforts. This was the first-ever wrestling show that Inoki promoted in the United States. The event, which also helped raise money for [[high school wrestling|wrestling]] and [[judo]] programs in [[Los Angeles Unified School District|Los Angeles-area high schools]], was supported by then [[Los Angeles Mayor]] [[Richard Riordan]] and [[Los Angeles County Supervisor]] [[Michael D. Antonovich]]. A few days before the show, Inoki was made honorary [[chief of police]] of [[Little Tokyo, Los Angeles|Little Tokyo]]. At the show's conclusion, Inoki was also awarded a special "PWI Lifetime Achievement Award" by ''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]'' [[senior editor]] [[Bill Apter]]. In addition, it received positive reviews from publications such as ''Pro Wrestling Illustrated'' and the ''[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]]''. This was supported by the [[internet wrestling community]] when it was released on DVD, albeit without matches featuring WCW wrestlers, years later. Arnold Furious of the professional wrestling section of [[411mania.com]] rated the event a 7.0 out of 10.{{cite web |url=http://www.411mania.com/wrestling/video_reviews/61849 |title=The Furious Flashbacks – World Wrestling Peace Festival 1996 |author=Furious, Arnold |date=December 10, 2007 |work=Video Reviews |publisher=411mania.com |accessdate=May 17, 2012}} In his review, Kevin Wilson of PuroresuCentral.com called Inoki's Peace Festival "probably the biggest show to ever take place in America" featuring international talent and that "the majority of the matches were good and a few were near excellent".{{cite web |url=http://www.puroresucentral.com/OtherPeaceFestival.html |title=World Wrestling Peace Festival 1996 |author= |work=Special Event Reviews |publisher=PuroresuCentral.com |accessdate=May 17, 2012}} The show is credited, along with AAA's ''[[AAA When Worlds Collide|When Worlds Collide]]'' show two years earlier, with helping introduce [[lucha libre]] to mainstream American wrestling fans.{{cite web |url=http://lucharan.tripod.com/wwc.htm |title=Cuando Los Mundos Chocan |author= |work=When Worlds Collide |publisher=Lucharan.com |accessdate=May 17, 2012}} [[Eric Bischoff]], who appeared with representatives from AAA and CMLL to open the show, later brought [[Rey Misterio Jr.]]Roberts, Jeremy and [[Rey Mysterio Jr.]]. ''Rey Mysterio: Behind the Mask''. New York: Simon and Schuster, 2009. {{ISBN|1416598960}} (pg. 140–141) and Chris Jericho into WCW, based on their performance in their respective matches, to compete for its [[cruiserweight (professional wrestling)|cruiserweight division]].{{cite web |url=http://www.geocities.com/smokyrobmoore/jp110899.htm |title=Sudden ImpactFul Thrillseekers' Record Book |author=Horie, Masanori |date=November 8, 1999 |work=View From The Rising Sun |publisher=Rob's Wrestling World |accessdate=May 17, 2012}}{{cite news |title='Breaking The Code' is a great look at Chris Jericho |author= |url= |newspaper=Sports & Recreation Examiner |date=January 21, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wwedvdnews.com/first-review-wwe-breaking-the-code-behind-the-walls-of-chris-jericho-dvd-iamjericho/4167/ |title=World First Review: WWE Breaking The Code – Behind the Walls of Chris Jericho DVD |author=Bee, Daniel |date=August 21, 2010 |work= |publisher=WWEDVDNews.com |accessdate=May 17, 2012}} [[Terry Funk]] was scheduled to face [[Sabu (wrestler)|Sabu]] and [[Brian Pillman]] in a three-way match, but pulled out of the show on May 8 after Pillman was sidelined following an automobile accident and Sabu was removed from the show after being booked for [[Big Japan Pro Wrestling]] (BJW) on the same date. ==Results== {| class="wikitable" width="100%" |- !'''No.''' !'''Results'''[[Pro Wrestling Illustrated]]. "Wrestling Supercards." ''PWI 2001 Wrestling Almanac and Book of Facts''. Vol. IV. No. 1. Fort Washington, Pennsylvania: London Publishing Co., 2001. (pg. 166){{cite web |url=http://www.softwolves.pp.se/wrestling/wcw/1996#peace96 |title=World Wrestling Peace Festival 1996 |author=Krefting, Peter |work=World Championship Wrestling 1996 |publisher=American Wrestling Trivia |accessdate=May 17, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/39081/this-day-in-history-world-wrestling-peace-festival-andre-debuts-in-canada-fight-the-power-and-more.html?p=1 |title=This Day in History: World Wrestling Peace Festival, Andre Debuts in Canada, Fight the Power and More |author=Woodward, Buck |date=June 1, 2009 |work= |publisher=PWInsider.com |accessdate=May 17, 2012}} !'''Stipulations''' !'''Times'''{{cite web|title=World Wrestling Peace Festival|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/usa/misc/miscindies.html#peace|publisher=prowrestlinghistory.com|accessdate=2012-05-20}}{{cite web |url=http://thehistoryofwwe.com/blog/2011/06/01/june-1-1996-battle-los-angeles/ |title=June 1, 1996: Battle: Los Angeles |author=Cawthon, Graham |date=June 1, 2011 |work= |publisher=TheHistoryofWWE.com |accessdate=May 17, 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://cagematch.net/?id=1&nr=59762&sortby=colLocation&sorttype=ASC |title=World Wrestling Peace Festival 1996 |author=Kreikenbohm, Philip |work=Events Database |publisher=Cagematch.net |accessdate=May 17, 2012}} |- |- |1 |[[Craig Pittman|Sgt. Craig Pittman]] (WCW) defeated [[Tom Howard (wrestler)|KGB]] (AAA) |[[Professional wrestling match types#Variations of singles matches|Singles match]] |6:11 |- |2 |[[Jim Neidhart]] defeated Bobby Bradley, Jr. |Singles match |5:00 |- |3 |[[Akira Hokuto]] (AJW) and [[Lady Apache]] (CMLL) defeated [[Bull Nakano]] (AJW) and Neftali (AAA) |[[Professional wrestling tag team match types|Tag team match]] |8:24 |- |4 |[[Chris Benoit]] defeated [[Alex Wright]] (WCW) |Singles match |9:54 |- |5 |[[Rey Misterio Jr.]] and [[Ultimo Dragon]] defeated [[Heavy Metal (wrestler)|Heavy Metal]] and [[Psicosis|Psychosis]] (AAA) |Tag team match |11:40 |- |6 |[[Lex Luger]] (WCW) defeated [[Masa Saito]] (NJPW) |Singles match |5:53 |- |7 |[[Negro Casas]] defeated [[El Hijo del Santo]] (CMLL) |Singles |[[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Trios rules (Relevos Australianos)|Six-man "Lucha Libre rules" tag team match]] |10:35 |- |9 |[[Tatsumi Fujinami]] defeated [[Victor Mar Manuel|Black page.title: Yogi Bear's All Star Comedy Christmas Caper

revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = Yogi Bear's All Star Comedy Christmas Caper | image = | image_size = | caption = | genre = [[Animation]]
[[Comedy]]
[[Comedy-drama]] | director = [[Steve Lumley]]{{cite web |url=https://us.imdb.com/title/tt1205608/fullcredits | title=The Internet Movie Database}} ''Yogi Bear's All Star Comedy Christmas Caper'' Cast & Crew | executive_producer = [[William Hanna]]
[[Joseph Barbera]] | writer = [[Mark Evanier]] | starring = [[Daws Butler]]
[[Don Messick]]
[[Henry Corden]]
[[Mel Blanc]]
[[Hal Smith (actor)|Hal Smith]]
[[Allan Melvin]]
[[John Stephenson (actor)|John Stephenson]] | music = [[Hoyt Curtin]] (musical director)
Paul DeKorte (music supervisor) | editor = [[Robert Ciaglia]] (film editor)
[[Larry C. Cowan]] (supervising film editor)
[[Gil Iverson]] (show editor) | company = [[Hanna-Barbera Productions]] | distributor = [[Taft Broadcasting]] | released = {{Start date|1982|12|21}} | runtime = 24 minutes | country = United States | language = English | network = [[CBS]] | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Yogi Bear's All Star Comedy Christmas Caper''''' is a 1982 [[Animation|animated]] [[Christmas by medium|Christmas television special]] starring [[Yogi Bear]]. It is the third and final Yogi Christmas special. Produced by [[Hanna-Barbera]], it first aired on {{Start date|1982|12|21}} on [[CBS]].{{cite web |url=http://www.bcdb.com/cartoon/70129-Yogi_Bears_All-Star_Comedy_Christma.html | title=Big Cartoon DataBase}} ''Yogi Bear's All Star Comedy Christmas Caper'' ==Plot== When [[Huckleberry Hound]] and his friends [[Hokey Wolf]], [[Snagglepuss]], [[Quick Draw McGraw]], [[Augie Doggie and Doggie Daddy]], and [[Snooper and Blabber]] visit Jellystone Park for Christmas, they discover Yogi Bear and [[Boo-Boo Bear|Boo-Boo]] have escaped from Jellystone and hidden out in a department store, where Yogi is posing as a Santa Claus. Along the way, he helps a little girl named Judy Jones rediscover her faith in Christmas when her father, a billionaire named J. Wellington Jones, is too busy for her. Yogi says that many parents have to work hard to support their kids, and since her father is not home, Yogi and Boo-Boo propose escorting Judy through the city to bring her to her dad. Ranger Smith and the others look for Yogi when they learn he and Boo-Boo are in the city. Yogi reunites with his friends, who help to look for Judy's father. In his search, [[Snagglepuss]] encounters [[Fred Flintstone]] and [[Barney Rubble]] as [[Street Santas]], who tell him to ask a passing lady his question. When the old lady screams in fear of Snagglepuss, Fred and Barney attack him, claiming it to be an entertainment purpose. Snooper and Blabber go to the police. Quick Draw has no luck, as [[Pixie and Dixie and Mr. Jinks|Mr. Jinks]] hasn't seen Mr. Jones; Pixie and Dixie leave a present for Mr. Jinks (which contains a bulldog). [[Magilla Gorilla]], [[Wally Gator]], and [[Yakky Doodle]] haven't seen Mr. Jones either, and since Yogi hasn't had any luck locating her dad's office, they take Judy to Jellystone to try to figure out a plan there. At Judy's home, J. Wellington Jones is troubled when his daughter isn't there, so he calls the police to help find her. Also working with the police is Ranger Smith, who is looking for Yogi and Boo-Boo. The police are at the department store where Judy was last seen, and [[interrogation|interrogate]] all the men who work as Santas. When they realize Judy went off with a Santa who wasn't a department store employee, they assume she was kidnapped. This accusation concerns Ranger Smith (despite having past problems with Yogi's antics, he can't believe Yogi would commit such a grave act). Snooper and Blabber were speaking to the Chief of Police at the time when word comes that Judy was seen in the park by a patrol car, and the Chief heads out to personally see the arrest of Judy's kidnapper. At the park, Yogi and his friends celebrate Christmas when the police arrive with Mr. Jones, accusing Yogi Bear of kidnapping his daughter. Yogi tells Mr. Jones that he needs to spend more time with Judy before she becomes an adult, but Mr. Jones denies it because he's busy all the time and is never home, only to then realize that Yogi is right. Guilty over his failure of being a good father to Judy, Mr. Jones tells the police to release Yogi by telling the Chief that it was really his fault that Judy ran off with Yogi, taking full responsibility for the whole debacle that's happened today, and Ranger Smith takes care of sorting out anything else the police would charge Yogi with. The special then ends with everyone singing Christmas carols around a campfire in the park. ==Cast== * [[Daws Butler]] as [[Yogi Bear]], [[Huckleberry Hound]], [[Snagglepuss]], [[Quick Draw McGraw]], [[Pixie and Dixie and Mr. Jinks|Mr. Jinks]], [[Hokey Wolf]], [[Augie Doggie and Doggie Daddy|Augie Doggie]], [[Snooper and Blabber]], [[Pixie and Dixie and Mr. Jinks|Dixie]], and [[Wally Gator]] * [[Mel Blanc]] as [[Barney Rubble]], Bulldog, and Security Guard * [[Henry Corden]] as [[Fred Flintstone]], Policeman, and Security Guard * [[Georgi Irene]] as Judy Jones * [[Allan Melvin]] as [[Magilla Gorilla]] * [[Don Messick]] as [[Boo-Boo Bear]], [[Ranger Smith]], and [[Pixie and Dixie and Mr. Jinks|Pixie]] * [[John Stephenson (actor)|John Stephenson]] as [[Augie Doggie and Doggie Daddy|Doggie Daddy]] * [[Hal Smith (actor)|Hal Smith]] as J. Wellington Jones, Sergeant, and Zookeeper * [[Janet Waldo]] as Mrs. Jones, Murray's Wife, Lady in the Street, P.A. Voice at Bus Depot * [[Jimmy Weldon]] as [[Yakky Doodle]] and Zookeeper ==Home Release availability== On {{Start date|1995|09|26}}, ''Yogi Bear's All Star Comedy Christmas Caper'' was released by Turner Home Entertainment on [[VHS]]{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Bears-All-Star-Comedy-Christmas-Caper/dp/6302874327 | title=Amazon}} ''Yogi Bear's All Star Comedy Christmas Caper'' VHS Release then a [[DVD]] of it came out on December 7, 2010 by [[Warner Home Video]].[http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Yogi-Bear-Yogi-Bears-All-Star-Christmas-Caper/14223 The Yogi Bear Show DVD news: Announcement for Yogi Bear's All-Star Comedy Christmas Caper | TVShowsOnDVD.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100818063448/http://tvshowsondvd.com/news/Yogi-Bear-Yogi-Bears-All-Star-Christmas-Caper/14223 |date=2010-08-18 }} ==See also== * [[List of works produced Bender 500]]'' ** ''[[Yo Yogi!]]'' * [[List of Hanna-Barbera characters]] * [[List of Yogi Bear characters]] ==Follow-up film== ''[[Yogi's Great Escape]]'' was released in 1987. ==References==
